df_descr.258: Five deeply engraved hour lines, the equinox, and the winter solstices remain on this dial fragment. The meridian is not preserved.
df_descr.259: Two preserved holes may have served separately or together as gnomon holders. One hole in the top of the dial is filled with lead and connected to the right edge by a groove 85 mm deep. A second hole, 10 mm wide, is situated 34 mm from the top along the right edge sloping up at an angle of 45. Six engraved hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on this southeast-facing half of a vertical deviating dial. The equinox and two solstices do not extend beyond the first hour line. Although the dial has been squared off along the left edge, a portion of the curved border remains. The top and right edge are smoothly perpendicular to the dial face. A large engraved B is preserved at the left end of the top edge. Evidence at the junctures of the wide hour lines and the equinox indicates that the former were engraved last.
df_descr.261: The engraved lines on this dial face include five hour lines, the winter solstice, the equinox, and the summer solstice. The dial appears to have been made to face southeast.
df_descr.262: Marucchi describes a configuration of four engraved lines which he suggests served to mark the positions of the third and ninth hours of the day between winter and summer solstice.
df_descr.263: A notably large gnomon hole, 13 mm wide and 45 mm deep, is preserved in the top center of the stone. Greek letters mark the nine divisions determined by ten scratched hour lines on this dial.
df_descr.264: A blood red color marks the eleven preserved hour lines and three day curves of this dial. There is no red color along the edges near the missing meridian line, and in fragment 7297 the left or meridian edge is finished smooth. The smooth lower edges of fragment 7297 also give some indication of the original shape of the dial. All preserved hour lines continue in red to the top center of the dial where a groove remains in fragment 7296. The two engraved hour lines in fragment 7297 continue beyond the lower day curve without red color. Note that while the hour lines are straight lines, the day curves are broken lines, the top curve most closely resembling a semicircle. The hour lines form the following angles between the left horizon and the eleventh hour: 19, 18, 15.5, 17.2, 14.1, 11, 10, 11, 14.7, 12.8, 17.5. The winter solstice curve consists of the following arcs: 9, 11, 9, 10, 8,,, 8, 11, 8, 10,  mm. The equinox curve between the horizon and the third hour line consists of the following arcs: 25, 26, 20 mm. the summer solstice curve between the sixth and eighth hour lines measures: 37, 31 mm.
df_descr.265: The publication describes a red copper bayonetlike gnomon. The dial consists of two plane surfaces meeting at an angle of 90 to form the meridian. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are preserved.
df_descr.266: Two joined fragments; Five hour lines are preserved, not including the meridian. Parts of seven day curves remain. A Latin inscription marks these day curves as shown in the figure.
df_descr.267: The preserved gnomon hole is 6 mm in diameter. Three circular arcs (with the gnomon hole as the center) are each evenly divided by eleven hour lines. Arc c_1 is approximately 103; arc c_2 is approximately 100; arc c_3 is approximately 96. The dial grid appears to have been designed to have functioned in the plane of the equator, inclined at an angle of 32 from vertical.
df_descr.268: The south face marks the seasonal hours when the sun is south of the celestial equator in fall and winter. Two side dials with faces parallel to the meridian plane mark the equinoctial hours before and after noon. The same gnomon hole with cross section perpendicular to the equinoctial plane once held gnomons for both the north and south face. The preserved gnomon hole is 6 mm in diameter. A horizontal line crosses the dial surface 31.5 mm from the top edge. Three circular sections (with the gnomon hole as center) are evenly divided by eleven hour lines. Arc $c_4 is approximately 75.8; arc c_5 is approximately 77.6; and arc c_6 is approximately 81$.
df_descr.269: A trace of metal remains in the gnomon hole (diameter is 4 mm). A long straight line from the gnomon to the bottom of the slab is divided into six parts by five marks. The divisions measure from top to bottom: 12 mm, 16 mm, 19 mm, 33.5 mm, 87 mm, and 152 mm.
df_descr.270: The empty gnomon hole has diameter 4.5 mm and is 16.5 mm deep. A long straight line from the gnomon hole to the bottom of the slab is divided into six parts by five marks. The divisions measure from top to bottom: 12.5 mm, 16 mm, 20 mm, 33 mm, 87 mm, and 150 mm.
df_descr.271: Seven hour lines radiate from a central point and cross four concentric circles. The preserved arcs of these circles are emphasized with red color.
df_descr.272: Photographs of this dial (negative numbers 54820 and 54821) indicate that it consists of a vertical disk facing east and west.
df_descr.273: The unbroken lower left edge of this southeast-facing fragment follows the curve of the summer solstice. Parts of all three day curves and one hour line are broken away at the bottom and the right side. All or part of five hour lines remain. A group of five convex flutes decorates the top edge.
df_descr.274: A gnomon hole is visible in the top of the dial above the meridian. Parts of three day curves and eleven hour lines are visible in a photograph of the dial. Only the meridian continues from the gnomon hole to the bottom edge of the dial. Other hour lines stretch between the solstices.
df_descr.275: Some lead remains in the gnomon hole in the top surface of this dial. The shadow-receiving surface of this dial is supported by a bull´s head and horns. The rounded back of the dial has the shape of a “feminine idol from the early bronze age.”  Eleven hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole across two engraved day curves to the lower edge. The dial´s top surface slopes downward about 15 from horizontal. In making my calculations I have assumed that the summer solstice coincides with the lower edge of the cylindrical surface. Ionescu-Carligel assumes that the two engraved day curves are summer solstice and equinox. He obtains g= 166.7 mm, \phi = 44.7.
df_descr.276: Seven hour lines (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9) and five day curves are preserved on the unrestored portion of this face. The configuration of lines suggests that the restoration as a roofed spherical dial is correct. Although this face of the dial is badly worn, the hour lines do seem to have once extended from the winter solstice to the summer solstice. The seasonal indicators c_1 and c_2, extending only between the fifth and seventh hour lines are marked. Three fragments have been restored (probably incorrectly) to the top of the sphere. At c_1 the solar longitude is Libra 28; at c_2 the solar longitude is Taurus 6. Geminus reports that Democritus observed the Pleiades on the fourth day of Scorpio; Euktemon observed the morning rising of the Pleiades on the thirteenth day of Taurus.
df_descr.277: Eleven hour lines extend between the winter and summer solstices. Five other day curves, including the equinox, cross these hour lines. A groove and circular depression suggest the former existence of a gnomon projecting from the bottom of the spherical surface. The summer solstice is inscribed. The inclined gnomon may have been placed in the plane of the equator.
df_descr.278: The winter solstice, equinox and a trace of summer solstice are visible. Six hour lines (as partially restored) extend from the winter solstice to the front edge. They divide the equinoctial line into the following segments measured from the base to the horizontal line near the top: 405 mm, 185 mm, 73 mm, 39 mm, 30 mm, 25.5 mm, and 17 mm.
df_descr.279: Five hour lines extend from the winter solstice to the front edge. The sixth hour line connects the winter solstice and the equinox. The hour lines divide the equinox into the following segments measured from the sixth hour to the horizontal line near the top: 185 mm, 70.5 mm, 39 mm, 34 mm, 24 mm, 16 mm.
df_descr.280: Upper south face: Eleven hour lines extend between summer solstice (at top) and winter solstice (at bottom). Five day curves cross the hour lines. The first and last holes are at the junctions of the horizon and the prime vertical. The middle hole is at the junction of the meridian and the prime vertical. The other holes intersect hour lines. The spaces between the day curves are indentified with Greek inscription as signs of the zodiac.  Lower south face: Three great circles meet at the east and west poles. Eleven cross lines extend between the first and second great circles. Thirteen cross lines extend between the second and third great circles. Shallow holes mark the east and west points and the junction of horizon and meridian.  North face: This configuration of lines closely resembles that on the concave surface of a roofed spherical variant dial. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are visible. A shallow hole marks the meeting point of the three day curves. A two line Greek inscription is preserved below the north face.
df_descr.281: Seven hour lines are preserved (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9). Three day curves are visible (winter solstice, equinox, and summer solstice). The area above the winter solstice is broken away. The hour lines do not continue beyond the summer solstice.
df_descr.282: Six day curves cross eleven hour lines. The hour lines do not extend beyond the upper and lower day curves.
df_descr.283: Five hour lines extend between the winter and summer solstices and cross the equinox.
df_descr.284: Five hour lines extend between the winter and summer solstices and cross the equinox.
df_descr.285: Restoration has obliterated any trace of a gnomon hole. Six preserved hour lines (morning hours) and the meridian cross three day curves.
df_descr.286: Of the eleven hour lines crossing three day curves, only the meridian extends beyond the summer solstice. The day curves are not parallel to the front edge.
df_descr.287: Three gnomon holes are visible above the top left side of the cylinder. The larger hole has diameter 7 mm; the two smaller holes have diameters of 5.5 mm. Five hour lines cross two preserved day curves. The measured distance from meridian to equinox along the top edge is 66 mm. The measured distance from the summer solstice to the equinox along the top edge is 53 mm.
df_descr.288: A gnomon hole, 7 mm in diameter, is visible above the meridian line. Five preserved hour lines cross three day curves. The surface is one half of a regular south-facing conical surface. There are no lines traced on the north-facing conical surface at top left.
df_descr.289: Lead remains in the 7 mm gnomon hole at the top right of the trapezoidal front section of the surface. Six hour lines cross three day curves. The meridian is not engraved. The distance along the meridian line from the right boundary of the truncated cone to the summer solstice measures 32.5 mm.
df_descr.290: Lead remains in a gnomon hole at the top left of the trapezoidal front section of the surface. Six hour lines cross three day curves. The meridian is not engraved. The distance along the meridian from the right boundary of the truncated cone to the summer solstice measures 50 mm. The distance along the meridian from the winter solstice to the left boundary of the truncated cone measures 10 mm.
df_descr.291: A gnomon hole, 11.5 mm in diameter, is visible below the lowest point of the front circular section. Five hour lines cross three day curves. The meridian is not engraved, but day curves continue to the implied meridian at the front edge. Two parallel curves, c_1 and c_2   are engraved at an oblique angle in the right half of the hemisphere. $ The arc bs subtends an angle approximately equal to 15.5 at the center of the sphere; be, an angle of 37; bw, an angle of 60.5; bc_1, an angle of 40; and bc_2, an angle of 62.$
df_descr.292: A gnomon hole 9 mm in diameter is visible at the lowest point of the spherical segment. Five hour lines cross three day curves. The distance along the unengraved meridian between the lower left boundary of the segment and the summer solstice measures 89 mm.
df_descr.293: A gnomon hole is visible at the lowest point of the spherical surface.  Six hour lines cross three day curves. The meridian line is engraved. The distance along the meridian from the right boundary of the spherical segment and the winter solstice measures 29 mm.
df_descr.294: The distance between cross lines on the right day curve is 34 mm. The distance between cross lines on the left day curve is 37 mm.
df_descr.295: The cross section of this cylindrical surface is noncircular. The preserved hour lines include 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11. The ninth hour line extends beyond the winter solstice; all other hour lines are contained within both solstices. The winter and summer solstice do not extend beyond the eleventh hour line, but the equinox continues to the top of the dial. The summer solstice curve from the seventh to the eleventh hour lines consists of the following arcs: 102, 56, 40, 35 mm. The equinox from the seventh hour line to the horizon consists of the following arcs: 40, 30, 30, 30, 21 mm. The winter solstice curve from the seventh to the eleventh hour lines consists of the following arcs: 19, 25, 25, 19 mm.
df_descr.296: A gnomon hole is preserved in the top of the dial above the meridian. The cross section of the cylindrical surface is noncircular. The preserved hour lines include 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. All hour lines extend slightly beyond the summer solstice but terminate at the winter solstice. Neither solstice extends beyond the first hour line, but the equinox continues to the top of the dial. The summer solstice curve from the first to the sixth hour lines consists of the following arcs: 35, 40, 56, 102, 129 mm. The equinox curve from the horizon to the sixth hour lines consists of the following arcs: 21, 30, 30, 30, 40, 42 mm. The winter solstice curve from the first to the sixth hour lines consists of the following arcs; 19, 25, 25, 19, 20 mm.
df_descr.297: Three hour lines (5, 6, 7) and three day curves are preserved. The cross section of the surface is noncircular.
df_descr.298: Das Gnomonloch ist etwa 5 mm breit und 12 mm tief. Im Inneren sind Bleireste zu erkennen. Ein zweites Loch befindet sich 5 cm unterhalb des Gnomonlochs auf der Meridianlinie und ist kaum 4 mm tief. Die Uhr hat 11 Stundenlinien und eine Horizontlinie. Die Stundenlinien werden von zwei halbkreisfrmigen Bgen geschnitten. Die Bgen haben einen Radius von 45 mm und von 141 mm. Mittelpunkt des kleineren Bogens ist das Gnomonloch des greren Bogens darunter.  Die Stundenlinien verlaufen vom Gnomonloch bis zum Rand der Platte. Die einzelnen Sektoren haben, von der Horizontallinie gegen den Uhrzeigersinn gezhlt, die Winkelgren 17, 16, 14, 15, 13, 13, 16, 14, 15, 15, 16, 16.
df_descr.302: Found on a piece of marble in a wall in Amastris.
df_descr.303: The inscription is part of a now lost sundial with spherical surface. The epigraphy dates from the early second century B.C.
df_descr.304: Found built into a wall of the house of Hussein Tschausch on Kos. The block of stone contained a gnomon hole and an inscription.
df_descr.305: A small marble base ornamented with a relief margin above and below was found on Lemnos. It contained a Greek inscription.
df_descr.306: Das Gnomonloch ist mit einer Größe von 32 mm x 20 mm und einer Tiefe von 28 mm relativ groß. Es ist gut erhalten. 11 klar gezeichnete Stundenlinien verlaufen vom unteren Rand der Schattenfläche bis zum Fußpunkt des Gnomons. Der Abstand der Stundenlinien ist gleichmäßig. Die halbkreisförmige Bogenlinie, die die Stundenlinien kreuzt, hat ihren Mittelpunkt im Gnomonfußpunkt. Die Neigung der Vorderfläche ist nicht einheitlich. Sie beträgt über den Füßen 41.5 und im Meridianbereich 38.5.
df_descr.307: Die Schattenfläche der hohlkegelförmigen Uhr ist präzise gearbeitet. Die Inschriftzellen sind über den entsprechenden Datumslinien eingemeißelt. Die Stundenlinien enden  offenbar an den Wendelinien. Einritzungen über der Winterwendlinie kreuzen zum Teil die Inschrift, außerdem sind Kratzungen entlang einiger Stundenlinien festzustellen.
df_descr.308: Sonnenuhr in mehreren senkrechten Flächen, oben gebrochen.
df_descr.309: Frammenti di meridiana in marmo con la raffigurazione die meridiani e die paralleli (lato interno lettere 2,8-3, bordo 3,5). Un´iscrizione è incisa sul lato interno, un´altra sul bordo. L´iscrizione interna alla meridiana riporta l´indicazione dei punti del triangolo entro il quale si allunga l´omba dello gnomone e segna gli estremi della durata dei giorni fra i due solstizi. L´iscrizione incise all´interno poteva contenere anche i segni zodiacali. L´iscrizione sul bordo esterno indica i nomi dei costruttori o dei dedicanti.
df_descr.310: This is a miniature. It is the only such dial made of ivory; it bears an inscription indicating that the lightning and shading of the undercut front face signaled the equinox; and it was found among its owner´s other effects in a private house. Seven day curves are incised, along with usual lines for the seasonal hours. The floating upper right corner cannot be joined to the main body of the dial, as too much of the ivory has been lost in between. All the incised curves and lines were emphasized with a red material. It shows the spectral signature of hematite. A length of iron nail remains embedded in a piece of ivory that carries a small portion of the dial engraving. This nail was not the gnomon, which has been lost.
df_descr.311: The central shadow-receiving surface of this dial is a convex cylinder with eleven hour lines and three day curves. The central dial is flanked by two deviating vertical dials facing southeast and southwest. Each deviating dial has three day curves divided by five hour lines with a gnomon hole above the meridian. A calendar showing the longest day equal to fifteen hours (\phi=40.56) is engraved on the base below the dial faces.
df_descr.312: Die sechs erhaltenen Stücke sind wieder zusammengefügt und ergeben eine 2-5 cm dicke Marmorplatte, die auf jeder Seite ein Liniennetz mit ähnlichem Aussehen trägt, nämlich Halbkreisbögen, die durch gerade, zu den hypothetischen Mittelpunkten führende Linien in gleiche Sektoren unterteilt sind. Die Linien sind fein, meist sauber gezogen und haben eine gleich bleibende Breite von etwa 1 mm. Der Stein ist im Bereich der großen Kreisbögen ein wenig gekrümmt. Die eine Fläche trägt eine nur noch teilweise erhaltene Inschrift. Auf ihr verlaufen die Strahlen bis unterhalb des Gnomonkanals, wo sie von einem kleinen Kreisbogen mit einem Radius von ca. 25 mm begrenzt werden. Ihre Verlängerungen treffen sich über der Kante. Auf der gegenüberliegenden Fläche, wo die Linien etwas stärker verwittert sind, gehen sie, zuletzt aber mit unklarer Führung, bis zum Gnomonkanal. Die Radien der beiden großen Kreise betragen auf beiden Seiten 294 mm. Der Gnomonkanal ist durchgängig, das heißt, der ursprüngliche Gnomon ragte beiderseits über die Schattenflächen hinaus. Sein Befestigungsloch wurde vom Gnomonkanal in den dünnen Stein hinein gemeißelt. Der Gnomonkanal verläuft schräg zum Stein und damit parallel zur oberen und zur unteren Kante. Der Neigungswinkel der Kanten zur Vertikalen hat einen Wert von etwa 40°, die Ortsbreite für das Amphiareion beträgt 38°19'. Der Stein ist im Bereich der Tagundnachtgleichen etwas dicker und der Gnomon ist auf beiden Seiten so kurz gehalten, dass die Schatten an den Äquinoktien die großen kreisförmigen Datumslinien treffen konnten. Auf der Winterseite, der Inschriftseite, lief der Schatten vom großen Kreisbogen des Herbstäquinoktiums zum kleinen Kreisbogen des Wintersolstitiums, wieder zurück zum Frühjahrsäquinoktium, um dann auf die Sommerseite hinüber zu wechseln, wo er vom Frühjahrsäquinoktium bis zum Herbstäquinoktium blieb.
df_descr.313: The base of a bronze gnomon in lead fill remains in the top surface above the meridian formed by the intersecting dial surfaces. This well-preserved dial consists of two dial surfaces, each with five engraved hour lines and three day curves, meeting at the meridian; one surface faces southeast, the other southwest. Some hour lines on the right extend beyond the summer solstice, but all seem to be contained within the winter curve.
df_descr.314: The publication describes a red copper bayonetlike gnomon. The dial consists of two plane surfaces meeting at an angle of 90 to form the meridian. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are preserved.
df_descr.315: Photographs of this dial (negative numbers 54820 and 54821) indicate that it consists of a vertical disk facing east and west.
df_descr.316: The equinox, the summer solstice line and a line neat the summer solstice are marked with Greek inscription. The dial is composed of transposed quarter spheres each engraved with five hour lines and four day curves.
df_descr.317: The transposed halves of a hemisphere form the shadow-receiving surface of this dial. On each side five hour lines stretch between the two solstices and across the equinox. The meridian line is not engraved on either side. An engraved line connects the equinoxes across the top of the dial. On the west facing side, the summer solstice continues from the hollow onto the plane surface. [...] Greek inscriptions mark the day curves.
df_descr.318: Surface 2. Hour lines on this face extend from the engraved winter solstice across the engraved equinox and summer solstice to the lower edge. The meridian is not engraved on either surface, but ten other hour lines are preserved.
df_descr.319: Surfaces 4. Measurements were taken from the better preserved west side segment. On it, five hour lines (7, 8, 9, 10, 11), winter solstice and equinox are scratched. The seemingly poor engraving job may only be the effect of weathering. The meridian probably coincides with the west edge. It is possibly that the lower edge marked the summer solstice. Measurements taken on the east side confirm those on the west.
df_descr.320: The right gnomon hole is lead filled. The transposed halves of a dished conical surface form the shadow-receiving area of this dial. The sagitta at the left equinox is about  8 mm; at right, 9 mm. Six hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on each side. Only the meridian continues above the winter solstice to the gnomon hole. Four day curves, engraved always equidistant from each other and from the lower edge of the dial surface, are visible.
df_descr.321: The hour marks are set on two opposing sides of this sandstone block. The top side has a cavity for the gnomon.  Catamo: The Naqca dial is of the conical type, with its vertex elevated (Gibbs §2a) only about 10 mm above the top surface, so that it closely resembles the rare type (§2c) in which this elevation would be zero. But this resemblance refers to the abstract geometrical properties only, not to the general aspect, which is quite different from the single case described by Gibbs, due to the considerable difference in latitude. Since in the case of Gibbs's §2c the hour lines are exact straight lines of equal length, they here deviate only slightly from such a geometrical layout: all eleven are 275±6 mm long and deviate no more than 9 mm from their full length chords in any place except one, namely that of the first morning hour. Day lines are lacking. The southern front plane is inclined by 18±2° to the vertical, with the uncertainty being due to some unevenness but still allowing agreement with the 16° of the local latitude. A unique feature occurs in that the northern front plane of the whole block is parallel to it and therefore parallel to the equatorial plane as well, so that it receives sunlight at any hour during exactly the entire summer half-year, a fact which allows it to be equipped with a second gnomon that projects its shadow onto it during the six summer months. Eleven radial hour lines are present accordingly. The two described inclined planes give the red sandstone block (apart from its base, which protrudes southward) the shape of a rhombohedron with all its twelve edges of roughly 450 mm in length.
df_descr.322: Sonnenuhr in mehreren senkrechten Flächen, oben gebrochen.
df_descr.323: Sonnenuhr in mehreren senkrechten Flächen, oben gebrochen.
df_descr.324: Con linee tracciate con vernice rossa. Asticella in bronzo pressoché integra.
df_descr.326: Non è facile trovare meridiane romane orizzontali complete di tutte le curve di declinazione. Gibbs ne riporta solo un paio. In questo caso c'è una stranezza-mistero: le curve di declinazione non sono sette, bensì solo cinque. Risulta essere l'unico esemplare disegnato con questa particolarità, ma questo lo vedremo tra poco. La lastra di marmo non è completa e della quinta ora è visibile solo un piccolo tratto mentre la prima è invisibile a causa della rottura nella parte sinistra. La linea meridiana si prolunga oltre i due solstizi.
df_descr.327: Nota: Nella catalogazione antica vi è una breve descrizione che dice: Frammento di una meridiana (quarto superiore sinistro) ricoperto di stucco bianco, con gnomone di piombo e raggi incisi e tinti di rosso. larghezza massima 0,37. Una nota di fianco al testo indica: restaurato - vi si è connesso lo gnomone. Ma tale scheda porta un numero di catalogo 1198 e non si tratta di un quarto di sfera superiore sinistra. Probabilmente c'è un diversità della catalogazione delle schede. La descrizione si addice piu' al frammento n° 20495. 17 Due frammenti molto rovinati uniti in malo modo. Possibile identificazione delle linee orarie dalla 2 alla 11. Tracce di vernice rossa su alcune linee orarie. Nella foto a destra si distingue molto bene la forma rettangolare del foro che ospitava lo gnomone e la colata di piombo fuso per bloccarlo.
df_descr.328: Un bellissimo frammento che conserva le ore dalle 7 alle 11. L'accuratezza del tracciato delle linee testimonia che un tempo era una meridiana davvero ben fatta. Conserva perfettamente la colorazione rossa per ciascuna linea e le due porzioni di solstizi.
df_descr.329: E' abbastanza grande di dimensioni, essendo di circa mezzo metro di lato. Semplice nel suo schema e completa, mancante pero' di gnomone dove c'è il foro triangolare semipieno di piombo fuso lungo 3,5 cm.
df_descr.330: Piccolo frammento di una meridiana orizzontale abbastanza grande. Si notano solo tre porzioni di linee orarie, probabilmente antimeridiane e questa decorazione che con un foro centrale fa pensare piu' qualcosa di simile ad un calendario.
df_descr.333: Scheda originale: Meridiana in marmo. Alt. 4,5 cm; lung. 13 cm Coll. Provv. Granai del Foro I St. A 1 B 1
df_descr.334: E' presente la base dello stilo in bronzo originale.
df_descr.336: Questa meridiana, ritrovata ancora da Peppino Cesarano ad Ercolano, proviene dalla Casa dell'Atrio a Mosaico e probabilmente era ignota a Gibbs o forse è stata ritrovata successivamente alla sua visita. Si tratta di una meridiana conica in marmo bianco con tracciato orario completo e ben fatto, come per quella della Casa della Gemma sempre in Ercolano. Sono presenti le tre curve di declinazione solare e tracce di ferro nel foro che ospitava lo gnomone.
df_descr.338: Tre fori nello spessore superiore, posteriore liscia. Data compilazione 1995 da Silvestri M.C
df_descr.339: Due frammenti: 1: Frammento di circa 50 cm di altezza. Visibile parte della curva solstiziale estiva e linea equinoziale. Una linea oraria identificabile con la 5 ora temporaria. Non vi possono essere dubbi sullidentificazione del frammento che era parte della meridiana complementare ortiva di inv. 112134. Frammento 2: Visibili 3 linee orarie, curve solstiziali e linea equinoziale.
df_descr.341: Descrizione della scheda del Museo: Frammento di lastra marmorea con meridiana. Marmo bianco a grana media. La lastra è fratturata a sinistra e superiormente, gli altri bordi sono conservati. Della meridiana disegnata con sottili linee incise si conserva la parte centrale a destra….. La parte oraria conservata è quella di sinistra, cioè la parte delle ore antimeridiane, come si vede dalla foto. La meridiana è davvero piccolina e molto fragile, ma pregevole nelle incisioni e nella fattura. Ben conservato il foro dove era alloggiato lo gnomone. Sono visibili 7 linee orarie, la linea equinoziale e le curve dei solstizi. Il reperto è spezzato in 6 frammenti ed incollato. Viene conservato in una busta di plastica trasparente sigillata.
df_descr.342: Sei linee orarie visibili. Equinozi e solstizi. L?incavo per lo gnomone e parte del basamento.
df_descr.343: Linee orarie visibili 3. Parte della curva del solstizio invernale.
df_descr.344: Manca buona parte del quarto di sfera sinistra. Presenti 7 linee orarie dalla Prima alla Settima e le tre curve di declinazione. Manca una scheda e qualsiasi descrizione. Ignota la provenienza. Ritrovamento casuale nei depositi da parte della consegnataria Panatta.
df_descr.345: Rifatto in gesso nella parte anteriore.
df_descr.347: Orologio solare di travertino ricavato in un parallelepipedo, manca lo gnomone; la parte inferiore poggia su mensole.
df_descr.348: Orologio solare su lastra rettangolare di pietra ad angoli smussati, mancante dello gnomone che doveva essere in bronzo: sulla faccia posteriore è incisa una ruota con vari elementi ornamentali, mentre una decorazione ad onde marine corre sui fianchi.
df_descr.349: Il blocco rientra dopo un tratto di cm. 8 formando una faccia rettangolare con scheggiature; su cui si trova l’iscrizione, su due linee (alt. delle lettere cm. 2,5) non completamente leggibili. La parte superiore aggetta e si incurva a formare la concavità su cui sono incise le linee delle ore (dovevano essere nove) tagliate dalle linee orizzontali dei solstizi e degli equinozi, alla base della quale si notano 2 rosette a 5 petali rigonfi, attorno ad un punto centrale.
df_descr.350: Esto conlleva que cerca del Solsticio de verano tengamos un día con horas de casi 75 minutos, y en los alrededores del solsticio de invierno las horas sean de unos 48 minutos. El reloj funciona bien sólo los días de los equinoccios en que tanto el día como la noche duran 12 horas. Tiene varias características que lo hacen algo distinto a la mayoría de los que se han encontrado: - La casi totalidad de los instrumentos de este tipo conservados tienen la superficie excavada para las horas formadas por una concavidad cónica y nuestro caso es de los pocos en que la excavación es cilíndrica, como parece ser que lo es también el encontrado en el arroyo Mazarracín en Toledo y conservado en el Museo de la Santa Cruz de esa capital. - Carece de líneas de declinación de solsticios y equinoccios. - El corte superior que debería ser horizontal, no lo es, teniendo una inclinación cercana a los 4 grados. Está fabricado en un bloque de arenisca cementada y, a expensas de un estudio posterior mas profundo, yo lo catalogaría como un "Hemicyclium" o Hemicírculo cilíndrico.
df_descr.351: Risulta che la meridiana è stata oggetto di studio da parte di alcuni studiosi tedeschi di cui pero' non è dato sapere altro, probabilmente per l'elevato interesse storico ed epigrafico dell'iscrizione presente sulla base del monumento e non ancora decifrata. Sono presenti 11 linee orarie e nessuna curva solstiziale ed equinoziale. E' rotta sugli spigoli esterni e non presenta tracce di foro gnomonico (il che è alquanto strano). Sotto l'iscrizione, sembra di scorgere due lettere DD che starebbero ad indicare forse l'anno di costruzione, il 200 d.C.
df_descr.352: This sundial dates from the imperial era and is an exceptional example of a scaphe, or bowl sundial, with a hole to let through a ray of sunlight. The interior is engraved with lines and inscriptions in Greek; the spot lit by the sunbeam would give the month, day, and hour. This sundial is in the shape of a skyphos or drinking vessel, a fashionable shape for luxury Roman tableware at the end of the republic. The exterior is decorated with oak twigs and acorns. The sundial was positioned vertically with the hole uppermost and the concave bowl facing the observer. The interior of the bowl is engraved with a network of curving lines accompanied by Greek inscriptions, some abbreviated, giving the dates of the Roman calendar. The broadest division corresponds to the summer solstice, 24 June, and the narrowest the winter solstice, 25 December.The fan of eleven lines dividing the curving sections marks the length of the twelve daytime hours of the Roman day, which were longer in summer and shorter in winter. The hole in the vessel let through a ray of sunlight that marked the month, day, and hour, moving round the bowl as the position of the sun changed. The opening would originally have been partly closed off with a bronze plaque, restricting the opening and thus focusing the beam more precisely, but this has been lost. The sundial was made for use at a latitude of 41 . If it was found in Carthage, which is at a lower latitude, it must have been transported there after manufacture. The shape of the vessel, the style of ornamentation, and the inscriptions seem to indicate that the object dates from the imperial era, some time in the 1st or 2nd century AD. The fact that the month of August is named augustus indicates that the piece dates from after 8 BC, when the month sextilis was renamed in honor of the emperor Augustus.
df_descr.353: La meridiana è esposta nel chiostro dell'ex convento di S. Francesco e pare non sia mai stata studiata fino ad ora. Non è stato possibile prendere le relative misure gnomoniche per mancanza di tempo, ma si spera di poterlo fare al piu' presto. Dalle foto effettuate da Luca, la meridiana si presenta come una meridiana sferica in discreto stato conservativo, quasi integra, in pietra porosa. Una parte del basamento è rotta, ma la conca sferica conserva intatte le undici linee orarie temporarie piu' le curve dei solstizi ed equinozi. Si può notare che in corrispondenza delle linee orarie Terza, sesta e Nona, esistono dei piccoli trattini profondi e trasversali. Probabilmente la meridiana fu utilizzata nel medioevo dai monaci per il computo anche delle ore Canoniche. Si nota bene anche la forma dell'incavo in cui era alloggiato lo gnomone. Fino ad un decennio fa la meridiana era conservata presso i magazzini della Soprintendenza di Firenze, poi trasferita nel chiostro suddetto. Una targa riporta che risalirebbe all'età repubblicana, prima età imperiale. Sconosciuta la provenienza e i dettagli del ritrovamento.
df_descr.354: Lo stato di conservazione non è molto buono, ma i suoi lineamenti e la sua forma sono ben distinguibili. La parte centrale del tracciato orario, ben visibile, mostra che esso fu realizzato con una buona precisione, certamente da mano esperta e che la concavità su cui giacciono fu concepita essere una sezione conica. E’ quindi una meridiana del tipo “Hemicyclium ad enclima succisum”2 classificabile come conica. La foto permette ancora di dedurre: - che le linee orarie originarie erano 11 e che se ne conservano in buono stato quelle dall’ora Terza all’ora Decima. - Sul bordo inferiore si vede tracciato molto bene un circolo che delimita la lunghezza delle linee orarie e che coincide, quasi sempre, con la curva solstiziale estiva; - Non sembra rilevarsi la presenza di un circolo equinoziale (linea equinoziale); - Risulta abbastanza chiara, anche se tenue in foto, la presenza della curva solstiziale invernale, come un piccolo semicircolo; - Tutte le linee orarie proseguono oltre il detto circolo del solstizio invernale per convergere approssimativamente nel punto di impianto dello gnomone3. - Nella parte superiore dell’orologio si vedono chiaramente i resti della base di piombo in cui era impiantato lo gnomone in piano orizzontale; - Il disegno della base dell’orologio sembra essere quello di solito comune a molti orologi solari greco-romani, cioè il rilievo di un tronco semicilindrico. Esempi di meridiane greco-romane senza linea equinoziale sono rari. Qui, in vero, non è possibile avere una certezza matematica, in quanto si riporta ciò che si riesce ad evincere dalla chiarezza della foto. Tuttavia, come per le altre linee, se linea meridiana ci fosse stata, dovrebbe esserne rimasta una pur minima traccia visibile, ciò che non sembra apparire nell’immagine.
df_descr.355: Elf Stundenlinien schneiden die sieben eingravierten Datumslinien. Am Boden der Halbkugel, dem ursprünglichen (?) Sitz des (fehlenden) Gnomons, ist ein Loch von ca. 70 mm Durchmesser herausgebrochen; ferner geht von Ost nach West ein (nach Auffindung nachträglich geklebter) Riss durch die Uhr. Der Durchmesser eines konzentrischen, horizontalen Kreisanrisses mit PES I und der horizontale Radius der Kugelausnehmung mit UNCIAE IIII zeigt erstaunlich glatte römische Abmessungen. Der Gnomon (Eisen/Bronze?) ist später herausgebrochen worden. Vielleicht war auch unten in der Halbkugel neben dem Gnomonsitz ein Loch zum Abfluss des Regenwassers vorgesehen. Der Urheber dieser Uhr hat die Dauer des Winters (absichtlich?) so angesetzt, dass die Winterwende genau in die Mitte fällt; dies ist das System des Eudoxos (13. November - 26 .Dezember - 7. Februar) bzw. das der Ägypter (1 1. November - 25 . Dezember - 7. Februar)! Auch die Sommerwende scheint in die Mitte der Dauer (?) des Sommers (ca. 15. Mai - 22. Juni- 01. August) gelegt worden zu sein. Der Schatten läuft hier zunächst etwa am 15. Mai und dann wieder um den 01. August entlang der zweiten Datumslinie von unten (Deklination +19°); die eingravierte Linie der Sommerwende wird jedoch nicht erreicht.
df_descr.356: Nely Tancheva-Vassileva riporta che la meridiana fu trovata nel 1995 durante la campagna di scavi archeologici della base militare romana di Kabyle, presso appunto il villaggio di Kabyle nel distretto di Yambol nel Sud della Bulgaria e che fu successivamente riutilizzata, almeno in parte, come materiale di costruzione per il palazzo vescovile. Il reperto risulta spezzato in due frammenti incollati. Undici linee orarie e tre curve diurne di declinazione sono incise nella superficie concava. Il foro per lo gnomone è ancora evidente, ma deteriorato. Presenta due tipi di decorazioni: la prima, sotto la superficie concava, ha due rosette ognuna delle quali ha otto petali e l’altra è una piccola palma e una gamba di animale (probabilmente leonina) stilizzata. Lo stile poco accurato delle decorazioni e la loro fattura rivelano la mano di un artigiano non molto esperto in questi lavori.
df_descr.357: Not much effort was employed on processing the marble. Greater emphasis was laid, however, on inscribing the lines and curves onto the shadow receiving surface. The eleven hour-lines originate from the base of the presently missing gnomon and extend towards the frontal edge. The midday line (for the 6tb hour) had previously been marked on the frontal plane - a mark also common for a number of other specimens. The so called day or seasonal curves are three in this particular case: they may often spring up some surprising information for the specialists. These ratios visually approximate 0.618 after the sundial is mounted and fixed onto a high place. Therefore it seems logical to assume that the sundial was constructed on the spot of its location and that point e' regardless of the slight errors in the value of 0 had been deliberately marked. Table 2 presents a comparison between some data read directly from the specimen under investigation and the results of computation. It could be seen in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 that the tip of the gnomon protrudes slightly beyond the space of the receiving surface and is a little above the horizontal plane. This can be accounted for by the repeated restoration of points O(f), O(h) and G during the construction of the sundial face and during the process of engraving the lines and curves of the dial. Fig. 4. shows that the vertical plane of the cross-section is not perpendicular to the axis of the gnomon but deviates with 3.40 from it.  A single explanation for the cause of that 'annoying' error can be offered: The clock (sundial) had been mounted and fixed onto a one-storey building with wrong orientation.
df_descr.360: Nella conca sono incise 11 linee orarie temporarie attraversate da un segmento circolare tracciato a 4 cm dal foro dello gnomone, e da una sola linea diurna di declinazione (equinozi) circa verso la metà della conca. Il blocco era incassato, probabilmente, per 2 cm come fa pensare l’incisione lunga 3 cm sotto l’iscrizione ed al centro. Alla stessa altezza, in ciascuno dei due lati del blocco, si nota un piccolo foro quadrangolare che, all’interno del blocco stesso, piega ad angolo retto, riuscendo sul fondo : qui, probabilmente, erano inseriti i perni che lo tenevano fermo al suo sostegno. Sulla superficie lavorata sono presenti scheggiature e graffi più o meno profondi causati da lavori agricoli. La rottura di uno spigolo della base ha portato la perdita di una lettera.
df_descr.361: This fortress sundial has 10 hour lines.
df_descr.362: The specimen from the Shumen Fortress have ten hour lines, which verifies the hypothesis for the existence of fortress sundials in antiquity, used for regulation of the change of dayguard.
df_descr.363: The fragment of the dial was found at the fortress. The day length was divided into 5 parts.
df_descr.364: Base con una lastra con entrambe le superfici verticali incise con tracciati orari ed iscrizioni greche (probabile orologio est-ovest, meridiano-occiduo come l’esemplare conservato nel museo dell’Abbazia greca di S. Nilo a Grottaferrata). Esemplare di rilevante importanza quindi. Trovato nel 1973. Lat. 42° 17’
df_descr.366: Il frammento è grande circa 30 cm e sembrerebbe appartenere ad un orologio solare emisferico. Si vedono porzioni di 6 linee orarie e due curve di declinazione corrispondenti al solstizio invernale e all'equinozio. Stranamente però non si nota un foro o incavo per l'alloggiamento dello gnomone sul bordo superiore in corrispondenza dell'ora Sesta. Ciò potrebbe essere spiegato ipotizzando uno gnomone disposto in modo diverso, come per esempio perpendicolarmente nel centro della vasca emisferica. In tal caso, solo il vertice dell'asta fornirebbe l'indicazione oraria e calendariale.
df_descr.367: Small fragment of a marble conical sundial, broken at the bottom, on the right and on the left side, preserving the hole for the support of a metal pointer on the top.
df_descr.369: IAph: White marble columnar altar; the diameter of the top surface, which is slightly oval, is 0.78 (north-south), 0.885 (west to east), to serve as a sundial.  Inscribed on the top surface, there is a hole where the gnomon may have stood.   Pattenden: This was a horizontal dial calculated to show the usual temporary or seasonal hours and of a pattern known from several Greco-Roman examples. Fifteen other such dials from different parts of the Greco-Roman world are cited by Gibbs. The gnomon cast a shadow across the pattern of lines and gave the time by the position of its tip in relation to the north-south grid of hour lines and the date according to the east-west lines, the northern hyperbola being the shadow-path on the day of the winter solstice, the southern that at the summer solstice, and the straight line that on the days of the equinoxes. A hole 3-2 cm across immediately south of the point where the equinoctial line crosses the meridian (the line running due north-south) marks where the gnomon, probably a bronze or iron rod set in lead, if other Greco-Roman dials are any guide, was fixed on the meridian. The gnomon itself may have been slightly inclined, but the shadow of its tip was what indicated the time, so that the lean, if any and position of the point of fixing are not important to the working of the dial.
df_descr.370: Six (afternoon-)hour lines divide two engraved day curves (winter solstice w and the equinox day curve e) leading to the lower edge (assumed to showing the summer solstice day curve s) of the spherical shadow-receiving surface. The break at the center has destroyed parts of the meridian and parts of the upper edge at the gnomon's origin, respectively. Also destroyed are parts of the ninth, tenth and eleventh hour line as well as parts of the equinox day curve beginning at the tenth hour line. The seventh hour line bears a marking parallel to the day curves. Traces of markings above the winter solstice day curve w on hour line VII and an extension of the hour line IX is visible. The broken right top corner shows a re-engraving of the day curve w and a corresponding extension of the hour line XI, respectively. Parts of the gnomon hole show traces of a working tool like a hollow-round blade. The obvious simple overall design includes a squared back. The (assumably simple sloping) base is missing. Preserved parts of the horizontal surface (reference plane) allow, by extrapolation of the meridian as well as of the day curves to horizontal intersection, a calculation and a reconstruction of the shadow-receiving surface by ancient geometrical construction (Analemma) and modern computer analysis. The fragment 79-OR-167 is part of a non-central spherical sundial with a non-centricity of Z(x) = 0.608 (radius of the sphere 150 mm, active length of the gnomon 91 mm, table 1). Being of average construction quality, the dial shows a construction latitude of 33.6° refering to the day curve e being the day curve for the equinox, and a using (latitude-) range from 31° to 40.5° (gnomon point in the horizontal top plane of the dial) for an obliquity of the ecliptic of 24 degrees (tables 2,3). Though the dial has clearly been designed non-central, the hour distances on the day curves do not follow the mathematical (and analemmatic) construction rules for non-central spherical sundials (Pergamon type, south facing). Despite of all inaccuracies the dial was able to display the time of the day in the ancient Herdonia with an 'average ancient accuracy.'
df_descr.371: Un orologio solare monumentale unico al mondo nel suo stile. Una seconda fortuna è che Olsson ha realizzato una foto ad alta definizione permettendoci di vedere l’orologio quasi come se fossimo sul posto, davanti ad esso. Grazie a questa foto possiamo apprezzare due caratteristiche uniche della tipologia di orologi solari “hemicylium” sferici: la suddivisione oraria e lo gnomone. Ciò che colpisce sono le dimensioni e subito il fatto di vedere incise nella superficie sferica una quantità di linee mai viste su un orologio solare di questo tipo. La prima cosa che ho pensato è stato: “vuoi vedere che questo orologio è una rarità in cui sono rappresentate le famose “semeion”, ovvero le mezzore”?1 Ingrandendo la foto, ho potuto contare singolarmente le linee constatando che esse sono 24 da un lato e dall’altro della linea meridiana. Siamo di fronte all’unico orologio solare dell’impero romano che mostra non solo le mezzore, ma addirittura i quarti d’ora! Come mai? Una delle spiegazioni più logiche è che date le dimensioni del blocco di pietra, era possibile realizzare con sufficiente cura il tracciato orario che comprendeva le mezzore, rendendone visibile la lettura anche ad una certa distanza. Ma ho pensato anche al fatto che una suddivisione oraria così fitta, si ricollega molto bene graficamente al simbolismo dell’aquila che presiede sulla parte superiore dello strumento. Inoltre le linee orarie non sono realizzate come nella semplice tipologia degli orologi ad hemicyclium, cioè incise nella superficie sferica con solchi di circa 2-3 mm di larghezza e profondità. Qui siamo di fronte ad uno stile che si riscontra raramente negli orologi solari. Ho visto qualcosa di simile nell’orologio emisferico di Petra, in Giordania, ma anche nel frammento di Paestum e in qualche altro raro reperto.
df_descr.372: Nella figura 4 si vede l’orologio emisferico sito nel 1994 probabilmente tra le rovine dell’antica città di Petra in Giordania. Ad oggi è l’unica immagine di questo orologio che si conosca, pubblicata su una rivista di viaggi, senza alcuna descrizione ovviamente. Si vede lo stile dell’orologio con le linee orarie in rilievo. Le ore sono intere, senza frazionamenti.
df_descr.373: Sono ben visibili cinque linee orarie nella superficie sferica superiore e sei linee orarie nella parte destra dell’orologio verticale in basso. Nell’ingrandimento dell’immagine è possibile vedere che i tracciati orari sono stati realizzati con molta cura ed abilità e stanno a dimostrare l’alto grado di tecnica raggiunto dagli artigiani gnomonisti nel II secolo a.C. Si conserva ancora il foro per lo gnomone orizzontale dell’orologio verticale dove, subito sotto, si vede la linea orizzontale di “alba-tramonto”.
df_descr.374: Come si vede dalle immagini, si tratta di un orologio multiplo formato, per quanto si può evincere, almeno da un orologio “hemicyclium” sferico superiore e di un orologio verticale meridionale nella parte inferiore. Sono ben visibili cinque linee orarie nella superficie sferica superiore e sei linee orarie nella parte destra dell’orologio verticale in basso. Nell’ingrandimento dell’immagine è possibile vedere che i tracciati orari sono stati realizzati con molta cura ed abilità e stanno a dimostrare l’alto grado di tecnica raggiunto dagli artigiani gnomonisti nel II secolo a.C. Si conserva ancora il foro per lo gnomone orizzontale dell’orologio verticale dove, subito sotto, si vede la linea orizzontale di “alba-tramonto”.
df_descr.375: Se vogliamo rifarci al catalogo di Gibbs, dovremmo dire che si tratta di uno “Spherical dial”, o al massimo di uno “spherical variant”, cioè di un hemicyclium sferico con qualche caratteristica diversa dalla normale tipologia, che nel catalogo di Vitruvio è riportato semplicemente come Hemicyclium. Tali fori, che ho potuto constatare essere di circa 5 mm di diametro e 2-3 mm di profondità, se non sono frutto dell’erosione della pietra nel tempo, possono essere addebitati più facilmente al lavoro di scalpellatura da parte dell’artigiano, che poteva forse usare un filo legato a piccoli pioli conficcati in questi fori per tracciare più correttamente ed in modo più lineare le linee orarie. Il frammento è abbastanza grande e indica che la meridiana originale era anch’essa bella grande. Sono presenti tracce di due sole linee orarie e di buona parte del solco del solstizio estivo distante circa 0,5 cm dal bordo estremo della conca. La cosa strana è che la distanza lungo il solstizio estivo delle due linee orarie è molto grande, ovvero di circa 13,5 cm tra le prime due e circa 14,5 cm tra l’ultima e la spaccatura di destra che pressappoco dovrebbe quasi coincidere con la successiva linea oraria. Non è quindi come le normali meridiane sferiche di questa grandezza in cui la distanza tra le linee orarie misurata lungo il solstizio estivo è di circa 5-6 cm.
df_descr.376: Meridiana sferica trovata a Pozzuoli e descritta da Aldo Adinolfi nel settembre del 1981. Non si hanno altri particolari. Dall'immagine (capovolta) la meridiana risulta coricata sul piano orizzontale. Tutta la parte esterna destra è andata distrurra. Si vede parte del foro in cui era lo gnomone e tracce di 8 linee orarie. Non si distunguono linee calendariali. Si ignora dove sia conservata. Sulla base ha la classica decorazione cilindrica.
df_descr.381: Eine fragmentarische und erodierte sphärische Uhr verfügt über 11 Stundenlinien und über zwei parallele Datumskurven im Bereich der Datumskurve für die Wintersonnenwende.
df_descr.382: Eine nahezu vollständige, jedoch oberflächlich sehr verwitterte sphärische Sonnenuhr, diese Uhr des Bovino Antiquario comunale verfügt über 3 Datumskurven und 11 Stundenlinien.
df_descr.383: Das Fundstück stellt ein Fragment einer offensichtlich auf einer Scheibe gedrehten, anschließend vertikal halbierten Schale (Wandstärke etwa 13 mm) aus mattbräunlichrotem Ton mit grauem Kern (unvollständiger Brand) dar. Auf allen Außenflächen des Fragments sind Reste eines hellchromgelben bis weißen Überzuges erkennbar. Durch die Standfläche (Halbkreis mit r = 80 mm; innerer, dazu planparalleler Schalenboden mit r ca. 48 mm; leichte Deformation durch Trocken- und Brennschwindung von radial etwa 5-8%) sind in einer "Mittellinie" senkrecht zur Vorderkante hintereinander zwei nicht ganz kreisrunde Löcher L1 (7 x 8 mm) und L2 (8.2 x 9.2 mm) vertikal durch den noch feuchten Ton geführt worden. Durch die nach Aufbringung der Farbe oder Farbglasur in den feuchten Ton eingravierten Linien ist das Fundstück als ein Fragment einer Sonnenuhr mit sechs partiell erhaltenen Stundenlinien (h4 bis h9) und einem um ca. 20 -24° zur Front geneigten Konstruktionskreis (K) interpretierbar; die von vorn gesehen linke Bruchkante stellt teilweise den Verlauf der 3. Stundenlinie (h3*) dar. In den Stundensegmenten IV, V und VI sind Reste von nach ihrer Gravur vor dem Brennen wieder glattgestrichenen ('ausradierten') Stundenlinien erkennbar; diese (tatsächlich) fehlerhaft angelegten Linien sind durch die auf dem Fundstück erhaltenen richtigen Stundenlinien h3*, h4 und h5 ersetzt worden. Weiterhin ist in die Anzeigefläche der gebrannten und an ihrem Platz aufgestellten und justierten Uhr eine in einem Meridianabstand (h6) von 36 mm zum Konstruktionskreis K eingeritzte (sehr schwache) Linie von etwa Anfang der hora VI bis ins 1. Drittel der hora IX erkennbar. Diese Information wird bei der Rekonstruktion wegen ihrer Unsicherheit nicht verwendet, jedoch später diskutiert. Es fehlt der gesamte obere Teil der Halbschale bis zum sogenannten Uhrenhorizont.
df_descr.384: L'immagine mostra un tracciato orario temporario delimitato dalle due curve solstiziali e intersecato dalla linea equinoziale. Si vede una porzione di tre linee temporarie alla sinistra della linea dell'Ora Sesta e quattro alla sua destra.
df_descr.385: Die Basis der Uhr erhebt sich über einer glatten Sockelleiste bestehend aus Hohlkehle und Wulst. Die Schattenfläche ist hohlkegelförmig und besteht aus elf Stundenlinien und drei horizontalen Datumslinien. Die Linien sind exakt und sicher in den Stein gezogen worden. Im Scheitel der Deckfläche liegt das Gnomonloch mit einem Bleibett, wie es bei der Verklammerung von Blöcken üblich war. Aufgrund des keilförmigen Ausschnittes zur Schattenfläche hin, ist von einem pyramidalen Gnomon auszugehen, wie er sich bei einer Uhr aus Athen etwa erhalten hat. Der Fuß des Gnomon und der Bleiverguss sind in der Bettung erhalten geblieben.  Karlheinz Schaldach:  Das Liniennetz wird der Ortsbreite von Ephesos sehr gut angenähert: auf der Uhr: 37°-37,30°, während sie tatsächlich 37,55° beträgt. Der Hohlkörper hat eine gute konische Formgebung und die drei Hauptdatumslinien für die Winterwende, die Tag- und Nachtgleiche und die Sommerwende liegen parallel zueinander. Nur die Ekliptikschiefen zur Winterlinie und Sommerlinie sind etwas zu groß. Bedenkt man jedoch, dass die Bögen der Randstunden kürzer sind und denkt man sich deshalb die Spitze des pyramidalen Gnomons etwas über der Deckfläche liegend - das heißt, der Gnomon war nicht bündig mit der Deckfläche sondern ein wenig erhaben angebracht - wird auch die Ekliptikschiefe genau angenähert. Die Uhr erweist sich so als sehr exakt konstruiert.
df_descr.388: Die Uhr war als Baustein eingebaut in einem kleinen Fundament eines Handwerkerhauses im zivilen Gewerbequartier nordwestlich des Legionslagers Vindonissa. Die Sonnenuhr besteht aus einem schalenförmig zugehauenen Kalkstein, in dessen Innenseite strahlenförmig Rillen eingegraben sind. Diese begrenzen gleichschenklige Dreiecke, welche die 12 Stunden des Tages angeben. Im gleichen Fundament lag ein weiterer weisser Stein, der Sockel der Sonnenuhr. Ursprünglich ist die Sonnenuhr aus einem einzigen Stein gehauen gewesen. Sie ist jedoch am Übergang vom Sockel zur eigentlichen Uhr auseinandergebrochen und repariert worden.
df_descr.391: Fragment from the face of a white marble sundial. Inscribed on the chord.
df_descr.392: La foto mostra un blocco di pietra quadrangolare in cui sono stati “scavati” quattro orologi solari visibili e dove probabilmente nel lato opposto ce ne sono altri due rivolti a Nord. Assumiamo che la parte frontale sia rivolta a sud, ci troviamo di fronte ad un orologio solare multiplo (Gibbs l’avrebbe forse definito “variante sferica”) composto da due orologi solari verticali e inclinati frontali congiunti nella linea meridiana. Ciò ci porta alla memoria il “Pelecinum” il cui tracciato orario è molto simile. Si vedono sei linee orarie per parte, compresa la linea meridiana verticale centrale, e le tre linee diurne dei solstizi ed equinozi. Nei lati Est ed Ovest si vedono due concavità all’incirca emisferiche che fanno pensare a due orologi, uno orientale e l’altro occidentale, ricavati su di esse. In dettaglio si distinguono anche qui sei linee per parte, più o meno parallele tra loro in direzione dell’osservatore, ed una linea per parte che le attraversa obliquamente, come si vede nei dettagli delle foto sotto. western hemisphere
df_descr.394: Di ottima fattura, conica, con solstizi ed equinozi.
df_descr.395: Si riconoscono le tracce di 5 linee orarie attorno allora Sesta centrale e una porzione delle due curve diurne del solstizio destate e degli equinozi. Nella foto a destra si vede il profilo della meridiana.
df_descr.396: Nel Museo di Storia di Hissaria, in Bulgaria si conserva una meridiana probabilmente di epoca romana. Sembra essere del tipo conica, in marmo. E presente un foro per lalloggiamento dello gnomone, la curva del solstizio estivo e undici linee orarie. Non si hanno altre informazioni.
df_descr.397: Veduta frontale della meridiana. E ben conservata con 11 linee orarie ben incise, le due curve solstiziali e la linea equinoziale.
df_descr.398: E ben visibile il cono gnomonica in cui sono descritte le 11 linee orarie e le curve dei solstizi ed equinozi. La forma della meridiana sembra infatti essere quasi una stilizzazione del formato ad eclima succisum laddove negli antichi esemplari era ben evidente il taglio del blocco della pietra secondo la latitudine del luogo, mentre qui il quadrante sembra essere stato pulito da ogni inutile presenza di parti marmoree non indispensabili a favore di una maggiore maneggevolezza data da un peso complessivo minore rispetto agli antichi blocchi di pietra.
df_descr.399: Die Anzeigefläche hat die Form einer angeschnittenen Halbkugel, in die sieben quer verlaufende Monatslinien graviert sind. Sie werden von elf Stundenlinien geschnitten. Die Spitze des horizontal angebrachten gnomon befand sich im geometrischen Zentrum der Kugel, seine Länge entsprach somit ihrem Radius. Errechnet man anhand der eingravierten Linien die geographische Breite, für die diese Sonnenuhr geschaffen wurde, erhält man eine Position zwischen 38° 28’ und 35° 51’. Diese Werte liegen recht nah bei der tatsächlichen Breite von 37° 10’, auf der sich Ai Khanum befindet; die Toleranz liegt bei 1°.
df_descr.400: Die Sonnenuhr war auf einer heute verlorenen Basis befestigt, so dass der Stein eine Neigung von 37,4° zur Vertikalen hatte. Ein großes Loch von 220 mm Durchmesser verläuft rechtwinklig zu den beiden großen Flächen A und B durch den Block. In die untere Wandung des Zylinders sind parallel zu den Außenkanten zwei Kreisbögen eingraviert, so dass zwischen den Rändern der Öffnung und diesen Linien zwei Streifen entstehen, die wiederum durch quer verlaufende Linien in zwölf Zonen unterteilt sind. Der Metallstab des 150 mm langen Gnomon, dessen Schatten entsprechend der Tages- und Jahreszeit wanderte, war in der Mittelachse der zylindrischen Öffnung angebracht. Die Uhr wurde auf ihrer Basis so aufgestellt, dass die große Fläche A nach Norden und die gegenüberliegende Fläche B nach Süden ausgerichtet war. Durch die Neigung von 37,4°, die annähernd der geographischen Breite von Ai Khanum (37° 10’) entspricht, lagen die Hauptseiten des Blocks parallel zur Äquatorialebene, der Gnomon war dementsprechend parallel zur Erdachse ausgerichtet. Bei dieser Aufstellung trafen die Sonnenstrahlen je nach Jahreszeit auf die obere oder untere Seite (A bzw. B). Zur Tag- und Nachtgleiche im Frühling und im Herbst fielen die Sonnenstrahlen parallel zur Neigung der Außenflächen ein, streiften also die Ränder der zylindrischen Öffnung, ohne dass der Gnomon einen Schatten auf die Wandung warf. An den anderen Tagen des Jahres bewegte sich der Sonneneinfall in einem Bereich von etwa 24° oberhalb bzw. unterhalb der Äquatorial-Ebene. Damit fiel das Licht von oben bzw. von unten immer weiter in die Öffnung ein. Entsprechend wanderte der Schatten des Zeigers bis zur Sommer- bzw. Wintersonnenwende auf den beiden, durch zwölf Stundenlinien unterteilten Bändern nach innen. southern part
df_descr.401: Seleukia am Kalykadnos: Byzantinische Sonnenuhr mit Inschrift.
df_descr.402: The sundial from Myrmekion near Panticapaeum is the most pan-Roman of the unusual sculptures from the Black Sea region, being a simple version of a carved and engraved block of marble produced for villas and town-squares from Ephesus to the environs of Rome. It is in the form of about the fourth part of a hollow sphere, supported on two large feline feet. The concave surface is graduated into twelve hour spaces, and there are remains of the attachment of the gnomon.
df_descr.403: Stone sundial, broken on the left and at the bottom right corner; decorated with the head of a bull in relief; on either side of the relief, traces of an inscription in six lines, erased in antiquity.
df_descr.404: A Matelica si trova un raro modello di orologio solare in marmo bianco risalente, con incisioni, segni e scritture greche, detto “globo di Matelica”.Il Globo o Sfera fu rinvenuto, nel 1985, durante le fasi di consolidamento del Palazzo del Governo, nel pieno centro storico di Matelica.  Il Globo è costituito da una sfera, del diametro di 29 cm., di marmo greco cristallino. Su di essa sono incisi centri concentrici, linee, archi, lettere e parole greche. Il Globo è un antichissimo orologio solare, adoperato per fare calcoli astrologici, astronomici e cronologici. E’ un piccolo “computer di pietra” che può essere usato, con buona approssimazione, per calcolare le ore del giorno dal sorgere del sole, la data di Equinozi e Solstizi, il calendario e l’entrata del sole nelle varie costellazioni zodiacali. Il Globo è una sorta di meridiana e deve essere esposto correttamente alla luce per poter offrire dati corretti: le zone di luce e di ombra vanno ad intersecare i segni e le linee incise sulla superficie  fornendo risposte corrette.
df_descr.408:
A dial of this kind would normally have 3 canonical calendar lines, which correspond to the winter solstice, equinoxes and summer solstice (tropai) respectively, like the example from Samos. More detailed than other examples, the scaphe of Kourion, is treated with a total of 7 calendar circles (one such example is spotted in Ain Khanoum) and it is tilting 60 degrees from all sides. Each calendar circle corresponds to the beginning of ancient months. Ideally, the Kourion sundial would work accurately in Cairo (Roman Babylon) or perhaps, Alexandria, and in Petra, Jordan which have a latitude identical to the tilting angle of the cone and the reading surface (30° - 31° 30΄ Ν) and was imported to Kourion, Cyprus, which has a latitude of approximately 34° 40' N. Gnomon length should have been 0.1673 m.

Text by Chrysanthos Kanellopoulos
df_descr.412: Exhibit 3a- The sundial. A stick, or pointer, had rested in the groove on top. The shadow cast by the sun would indicate the time. This sundial was found in the remains of Temple stones. It is believed that it was used in the Bais HaMikdash to mark the time. Exhibit 3b- The base of the sundial. It is one of the very rare depictions of the menorah made while the Bais HaMikdash was still standing.
df_descr.413: Rectangular stone sundial; two fragments; larger, left-hand, fragment bears hour divisions XI and XII, third digit of second numeral apparently effaced by the split between the two fragments; smaller, right-hand, fragment bears the hour division I.
df_descr.416: Sono visibili 8 linee orarie, la linea equinoziale centrale rispetto al tracciato orario e il piccolo cerchio (in corrispondenza del solstizio infernale) da cui si dipartono le linee orarie. Non si anno altri dati.
df_descr.417: Raffaele Farese con il quale ho potuto stabilier una collaborazione reciproca che ha portato alla divulgazione nel nostro ambito gnomonico di questa meridiana di pregevole fattura. In linea di massima si tratta di una meridiana sferica con undici linee orarie temporali e tre linee solstiziali. E’ conservata ottimamente e non presenta particolari fregi sulla base. Sul retro, in prossimità del punto di convergenza delle linee orarie, è visibile un foro che serviva probabilmente all’incastro dello gnomone orizzontale. Una inclinazione inspiegabile, ovviamente. Ma non è tutto, dai calcoli effettuati, Huttig ha rilevato che la superficie concava della meridiana non risulterebbe essere una sfera, ma un “ellissoide rotazionale”! E Huttig si chiedeva: “Perché un ingegnere avrebbe scelto una forma cosi’ complicata? Si puo’ pensare che ci fosse un’altra meridiana veramente sferica prima che fosse “cancellata” (rubbed out) per qualche ragione ottenendo come risultato questa nuova forma? Il mio parere è molto piu’ semplice ed ho sempre pensato che la lavorazione artigianale di queste meridian non si astata semper semplice e precisa. Io sarei piu’ propenso nel credere che si tratti di un errore di costruzione, non so quanto rilevante ai fini della lettura dell’ora sulla meridiana, ma non credo che influisca notevolmente.
df_descr.419: Il tracciato orario è del tipo classico, ma le linee sono tracciate su una superficie concava, né sferica, né conica e sono limitate dalle linee solstiziali. Inolgtre il tracciato non è molto regolare, come sarebbe nel caso di una superficie sferica o conica e le linee attorno al sorgere e tramontare del sole son omolto piu’ ristrette rispetto a quelle meridiane centrali. Ciò è dovuto alla strana forma concava della superficie che tende a far prendere alle linee delle forme quasi ellittiche o a forma d’uovo. La latitudine calcolata da Parés è compresa tra 43 e 44 gradi che corrisponde bene a quella di Lune-Viel.
df_descr.420: Questa bella meridiana è tronca per buona parte della superficio superiore (oltre la metà sul bordo superiore). Si contano 7 spazi orari i quali, al contrario di come scrive Pititto nel suo testo, non sono regolari “di uguale ampiezza”, come mostra evidente la foto, ma piu’ larghi nelle ore vicino al mezzogiorno e piu’ stretti tra le altre linee orarie. Forse si tratta di un tracciato non troppo preciso. Ben evidente è la curva equinoziale la cui presenza indica certamente che era presente anche quella del solstizio invernale e quindi quella del solstizio estivo corrispondente al taglio della concavità sferica inferiore. “Il Basamento, che presenta un grosso foro semicircolare, è ornato da due animali accovacciati con la testa mancante. Al centro si trova una sfera fasciata da tre anelli disposti a 120°”, è la descrizione finale di Pititto che ringrazio per le informazioni e per la gentile concessione del materiale qui pubblicato.
df_descr.422: The seating for the gnomon, a rectangular incision of 30 x 15 x 5 mm, is still visible (see figure), as are the solstice curves, the equinox curve, and eleven hour lines. The workmanship is rather rough and the block is not squared well. The edge of the upper horizontal face would seem to be a circle, although the dimensions available do not provide enough evidence for us to be sure of this. However, the noon hour line, which is a generator of the cone, is perfectly straight.  It has one anomalous feature for a conical sundial: the distance on the noon hour line between the winter solstice curve and the equinox curve is equal to the distance between the latter and the summer solstice curve. This precludes the mathematical calculation of the angle between the axis of the cone and the noon hour line, which is a generator of the cone, and it is therefore impossible to calculate the intended latitude. The angle between the oblique front of the dial and the rear vertical plane is about 40°, not very different from the latitude of Vulci, which is nearly 42°. The hour lines divide the solstice and equinox curves at points that are only approximately equidistant. To calculate the intended latitude with the other usual methods  the average values of these arcs can be used, giving about 66° from each solstice curve, very different from the true latitude of  Vulci. The presumably arbitrary positions of the hour lines seem to support the thesis of Hüttig, according to which the day curves of conical sundials were often traced as auxiliary elements, divided into twelve equal intervals and uniting the corresponding points with straight arcs, in order to obtain the hour lines and not to represent the real solstice and equinox curves. The conclusion is that the conical sundial from Vulci was not built with great precision.
df_descr.423: Si dice che la meridiana fosse usata dalle lavandaie per batterci i panni sopra. E’ in buono stato di conservazione. Presenta gli spigoli superiori danneggiati e la zona del buco che conteneva lo gnomone. Nella cavità vi sono incise 11 linee orarie temporarie attraversate dalle tre linee di declinazione per il solstizio invernale, gli ezionozi e il solstizio estivo. Due fregi in rilievo sui lati, appena sotto la cavità conica, ed un altro disegno al centro decorano questa bella meridiana. Tali segni sono stati riscontrati su una tomba di Tarquinia e sullo scudo di un guerriero etrusco di Volterra.
df_descr.424: La meridiana si presenta danneggiata sui due lati esterni della conca che contiene 11 linee orarie. Non sono visibili linee di declinazione per i solstizi e gli equinozi.
df_descr.427: A Hellenistic sundial not contained in the standard catalogue by Gibbs. This example is unique in being made of plaster, in its small size, and in having a shadow-receiving surface of negative, roughly hyperboloidal curvature. As is shown by the location of the eleven hour lines, the lost gnomon was undoubtedly placed as usual within the horizontal upper plane, and the twelve hour segments show equal breadth with an accuracy netter than average. The maximum indivation of season possible with this design would have been achieved with a gnomon tip adjusted to the centre of the circular edge line, so as to have its shadow on the face during the winter half of the year and off the face in summer. Although these features are satisfactorily represented, the sundial has a minor defect in that the horizontal top surface as described above is clearly not parallel to the plane at the bottom of the base, a fact that can be explained only as a mistake or as a subsequent adaption to an oblique support.
df_descr.432: By cutting through the length of the block at an angle of 33" from the vertical (fig. 3, photograph 3) a surface 44 cm. long by 39 cm. wide was formed (fig. 1). On this reclined surface at approximately 30 cm. above the projected bottom edge of the stone a horizontal line, AB, at least 41 cm in length, was scribed. Below line AB and at its center, point Z, three semi-circles with radii of 11 cm, 12.5 cm, and 20.5 cm, respectively, were cut. At every 15" of arc around the 1800 of the semi-circles, lines radiating from point Z were scribed between the semi-circumference of the 11 cm radius semicircle and that of the 20.5 cm radius semicircle. In this manner eleven scribed lines divided the area between the innermost and outermost semicircles into twelve equal sectors. Vertical line GC, 21 cm long, was scribed perpendicular to line AB (fig. 1). At point G, 3 cm below point Z, a 1 cm square, 4 cm deep hole with sides perpendicular to the reclined surface had been cut (fig. 3). The hole was partly covered by a flow of lead, in the center of which had been formed a square hole approximately 1 cm on each side. It seems clear that at one time a metal gnomon had been fitted into the hole and had stood perpendicular to the 33" reclined surface. As one faces the reclined surface with its inverted and regularly divided semicircles which form the face of Sundial 1 (figs. 1 and 2, photograph 1), traces of ten inscribed Greek capital letters, 1.5 cm high, can be seen to the right of each of the scribed lines, radiating from point Z at intervals of 15 of arc.
df_descr.434: The concave dial is divided by incised lines into twelve radial segments.
df_descr.445: The dial face is badly damaged.
df_descr.452: The face shows the eleven hour lines, the equinox and the two solstitial curves. These three day curves are divided by approximately equidistant points of intersection with the hour lines. On the noon hour line, the distance of the equinox curve from the winter and summer solstitial curves are 44mm and 72mm, respectively. Applying commonly used methods of calculation, we find that the angle between the axis of the cone and the generator of the conical surface is 30.5° and the resulting original gnomon length is 88mm. On the basis of these data the intended latitude is 40°, agreeing admirably with the 40.8° of the site. Consequently, the conical sundial from Villa A of Oplontis is of very good accuracy.
df_descr.454: Two rather inexactly made miniature spherical dials in stone can be mentioned. One, in the Archaeological Museum of Rhodes, the other, in Syracuse is almost complete.
df_descr.455: La meridian ad emiciclo trovò un´ampia diffusion come orolgio solare el mondo Greco-romano. Derivò da una genial intuizione del babilonese Beroso (IV sec a.C.): l´emisphericum che consisteva in uns semisfera che riproduceva  rovesciata la colta celste con al centro uno gnomon vertical di lunghezza pari  al raggio della sfera. In seguito al ritrovamento di un frammento di meridian ad emiciclo (circa la metà) avvenuta a Mardimago in località Bernadetta (sito A 39), il Gruppo Astrofili Polesani è stato incaricato a riconstruine un  modello che ne ritoducesse l´intera semiazza originale. La suddivisione oratia dell´emiciclo venne effettuata in portionei uguali die 15 ognina perché così sembrava essere stat effettuata sull´originale ritrovato e così appariva nelle diapositive di alcune meridiane antiche.
df_descr.457: It shows the eleven hour lines, the equinox and the two solstitial curves, all quite irregular. The solstitial curves are almost equidistant from the equinox line, as theory requires, 18 namely 245mm and 250mm. The diameter of the equinoctial circle is therefore 451mm. Applying commonly used methods of calculation, we find that the intended latitude is 40.5°, to be compared with the 40.8° of Torre Annunziata. We conclude that the spherical sundial from Villa B of Oplontis is of good accuracy.
df_descr.458: Three small fragments (see figure) of a light limestone vertical deviating sundial, now in the City Antiquarium of Guidonia Montecelio, were found on different occasions in the countryside of Guidonia, a small town near Tivoli. The fractures of two of these pieces match, so they can be put together, while the third piece is from a different part of the sundial. The reassembled fragment is 115mm high, 200mm wide and 7mm deep. The dimensions of the detached fragment are 146mm by 16mm by 27mm. The noon hour line is completely missing, so it is difficult to make the usual calculations to determine the intended latitude. Consequently, the author has attempted an inverse procedure from the one normally followed when studying a sundial: the object was reconstructed starting from the reasonable hypothesis that it was built for the latitude of 42°, the latitude in which it was found. The angle between the equinox line and the upper edge of the fragment, assumed to be horizontal, was measured and found to be 40°, from which a deviation 49° west can be deduced. On the basis of these figures, the author made a drawing of a vertical deviating sundial which would seem to correspond quite well if the perpendicular height of the gnomon was about 130mm. In the example, the winter hyperbola appears higher than that calculated astronomically, a situation that is not rare in ancient sundials of imprecise workmanship. Through the reconstruction it was possible to identify, with good approximation, the position originally occupied by the third fragment, which contains a small part of the summer solstice curve. The shape of the cut stone slab must have been something like a triangle, with two straight sides - the upper horizontal and the noon vertical - and the third an arc approximately parallel to the summer solstice curve. It is clear, in fact, from the third fragment that this arc is not the result of a fracture but was carefully worked by the builder, who engraved an X in the concavity, rotated by 90° and delimited by two small vertical bars.
df_descr.459: A light-colored marble vertical deviating sundial, in a good state of conservation (see figure), was found on the site of some Roman buildings.  The sundial is inscribed with the winter solstice curve, completely preserved; the summer solstice curve, about half of which remains; and the equinox line, almost all of which remains. There are six hour lines. The usual methods of calculation give an intended latitude of about 39°, little differing from that of the place where it was found, namely 42°. To judge from the slope of the equinox line, the face of the sundial probably deviated from the prime vertical by 36° west. The length of the gnomon, according to the calculations, was 58mm. The test of the distance along the equinox line between the noon line and the first hour after noon gave the following results: calculated 35 mm, measured 44 mm. Taking everything into account, the conclusion is that this sundial was built with a relatively good degree of accuracy.
df_descr.460: Bonanome: The flat surfaces of this solar instrument have been carved and rubricated (i.e., colored in red) to make their reading easier, since they acted as sequential dials. This means that a dial is designed to be faced to the East, in order to show the morning hours, whereas the other is faced to the West and shows the afternoon hours. On both surfaces, a mirrored pattern of vertical and horizontal lines called analemma reproduces the part of the daylight hours corresponding to the East and West cardinal points. The line AEB marks the horizon, from where three different lines start. Two lateral hyperbolas, slightly declining, AA and BB mark the course of time during the solstitial period: it is shorter in the summer solstice (AA) around the 21st June, when the sun is on the highest point above the horizon, and longer in the winter solstice (BB), around the 23rd December, when the sun is on the lowest point above the horizon. Between those two lines there is the equinoctial line (EEE), relating to the days of the spring equinox of the 21st March, and to the autumnal equinox of the 23rd September. This line is more or less inclined depending on the cardinal point the dial is facing. The six horizontal secant lines, starting from AEB and ending to AEB, after being calibrated on the Eastern and Western dials, mark the six sectors in which the hours are divided: in ante meridiem (a.m.) and post meridiem (p.m.) respectively. As we can see in the drawing, these six lines marking the passing of time are more clustered near the noon line because the sun moves slower in that phase.
