Therefore, the hour could be read looking at the tip of the shadow cast on the dial by the gnomon or style (that is the metallic element placed in a pre-arranged point of the analemma) which follows the motion of the sun across the sky. To determine the length, the position (orthogonal or inclined), the insertion point of the gnomon along the line AEB which marks the horizon, and to draw the declining segments crossed by the secant lines of the hours of the analemma, complex gnomonic calculations are required. In the sundial we are discussing on, two gnomons have been placed halfway along the horizontal line AEB. Of these gnomons, only the pins still inserted in the marble slab and the lead used to solder them remain visible. Another characteristic of this sundial is the presence of a third gnomon. Similarly to the two other, it is marked by the soldering lead still present on the outer rim of the marble frame. Its insertion angle is particularly acute, probably due to the need of being in axis with the sun at noon of the equinoctial days. This, in turn, was probably devised to make calibration and periodic checks of the instrument easier. However, at a closer examination, one can see that in the insertion point of this gnomon two straight carved lines intersect. They were once rubricated and are perpendicular: the vertical line is longer than the horizontal one because the dial border does not limit it. One can also see that the horizontal line must have continued to be overlapped onto the horizontal line of the Eastern analemma. Vice versa, the latter should have continued to reach the unfortunately damaged horizontal line of the Western dial. Since the point where the lines on the rim intersect is exactly the same as that of the third gnomon, it is more correct to believe that this system could have been used to follow the motion of the gnomons shadow from one dial to the other. In other words, this system gave the observer the opportunity to read the time from below also during the delicate passage from the ante meridiem to the post meridiem position of the sun.

df_descr.462: Il est en assez bon état de conservation, malgré l’absence des ailes latérales, brisées, et du gnomon, dont on devine l’emplacement par une cavité de trois centimètres de profondeur. Il présente onze lignes horaires gravées nettement dans la pierre, et trois courbes de déclinaisons.
df_descr.463: Du cadran, n’est conservé que la partie orientale de la surface réceptrice. On n’observe donc que les lignes horaires de l’après-midi. Le fragment ne présente aucune courbe solsticiale ou équinoxiale.
df_descr.464: Les extrémités frontales et latérales ont entièrement disparues, le gnomon est bien évidemment manquant, mais son emplacement est encore perceptible. Le cadran ne possède toujours pas de courbes de déclinaisons horaires (équinoxiales et solsticiales) et présente le réseau habituel des onze lignes temporelles.
df_descr.465: Sa forme est peu commune dans le corpus des cadrans romains, et sa réalisation technique très négligée. Ainsi, il est difficile d’en définir la typologie, que nous laisserons volontairement «indéterminée». L’arc gravé non loin de l’emplacement du gnomon est probablement décoratif, il ne s’agit absolument pas de la courbe du solstice d’hiver. Les lignes horaires sont gravées de façon irrégulières, et ne sont pas espacées logiquement ni géométriquement. Il en résultait ainsi un fonctionnement très approximatif, loin des «canons» gnomoniques de l’époque.
df_descr.466: On retrouve les onze lignes horaires ainsi qu’un cercle intermédiaire, qui, comme pour le cadran de Vilanova, évoque plus une représentation de la ligne équinoxiale qu’une réelle courbe de déclinaison utilisable. Le centre du cadran n’est pas situé dans l’axe du cône comme il devrait l’être mais à la base du gnomon L’angle entre la face frontale et la verticale est de 29°, ce qui ne correspond pas à celui de Mazaracín, à peu près 40°. La face frontale n’est ni perpendiculaire à l’axe de la terre, ni à l’axe du cône. L’ensemble est donc très approximatif.
df_descr.467: Seule la partie occidentale, présentant les lignes post-meridiem, est conservée. Il ne semble pas y avoir de lignes solsticiales ou équinoxiales.
df_descr.469: On peut distinguer sur le fragment les courbes de déclinaisons.
df_descr.471: Il s’agit de deux fragments d’un cadran conique retrouvés entre 1985 et 1987 sur le site de la villa romaine de Freira. Cette villa se trouve aujourd’hui sur la paroisse de S. Domingo de Ranas, Cascais. Nous ne possédons pas d’autres informations sur ce cadran.
df_descr.474: La partie supérieure de l’objet présente deux ailes latérales où se trouve gravé un réseau de lignes qui ne sont pas symétriques et régulières. La partie inférieure, un piédestal de forme circulaire, porte une inscription en lettres grecques, rédigée dans une langue ibérique. Si la partie supérieure laisse tout de suite penser à un cadran solaire de type pelecinum, comme nous l’avons vu représenté sur le sarcophage de Murcia, la partie inférieure est sujette à caution. Très vite, l’objet a suscité des doutes et fut classifié comme un faux dans sa totalité par la critique étrangère. À cela plusieurs raisons. Tout d’abord, on ne connaît pas de cadrans de ce type dans le corpus des objets retrouvés. Il ne se trouve représenté qu’en iconographie. Ensuite, il est inutilisable en tant que cadran solaire, les lignes étant très fantaisistes (tout comme sur la majorité des représentations iconographiques). Concernant l’acquisition, l’époque de découverte et de vente coïncide avec une période de création de faux en tout genre, surtout dans la région du sanctuaire de Yecla. Enfin, la typologie, le pelecinum, est typique du III-Ive siècle de notre ère.
df_descr.478: This sundial has a surface which is separated in 12 parts representing 12 hours of the day. More particularly, the sundial consists of a hyperbola tracing the shadows path at the winter solstice, a second one for the summer solstice, and a straight east-west line in between marking the equinoctial shadows. A line from the base of the gnomon to the south of the dial running due north denotes noontime. The hyperbola is centered on this noon line. The winter hyperbola opens to the north, the summer hyperbola to the south. In addition to the center noon line, additional oblique lines are added on either side to denote the hours of daylight before and after noon.
df_descr.482: Frammento di presunta meridiana di epoca romana, conservato al Museo della Bonifica di San Donà di Piave. Reperto segnalato da Renis Ridolfo e presentato nel blog http://digilander.libero.it/rossi7871/VE0126.htm Dall'user "rossi7871". Sono visibili parte di 4 linee orarie e di due curve di declinazione corrispondenti al solstizio invernale e agli equinozi. Il tracciamento delle linee lascia pensare ad un orologio di fattura abbastanza modesta e non è escluso che posa trattarsi di un reperto di epoca molto tarda, forse anche bizantina, o addirittura altomedievale.
df_descr.484: Cinque frammenti pertinenti a un orologio solare di tipo piano in marmo bianco (misure delloggetto integro: circa 80 x 40 cm). Sulla lastra di marmo sono incise una serie di linee che formano un disegno a doppia scure (pelecinum); al centro si riconosce ancora lincavo per lo gnomone.
df_descr.485: Am 16. August 1998 wurde beim Abbruch eines neuzeitlichen Hauses in Eretria eine Sonnenuhr gefunden und gleichentags in das Museum verbracht. Die Sonnenuhr war als Baumaterial in dem modernen Haus wiederverwendet worden, worauf auch die Beschädigungen auf der Vorderseite des ansonsten in seinem antiken Bestand erhaltenen Marmorblocks zurückzuführen sein dürften. Weitere Spuren der Verbauung finden sich vor allem auf der besser erhaltenen Schmalseite in Form einer feinen Mörtelschicht. Der Fundort liegt auf dem Grundstück 815 des Gesamtplanes von Eretria, im nördlichen Teil der Unterstadt, nahe dem Akropolis-Südfuss.  Da der Marmorblock, aus dem unsere Uhr gehauen wurde, mit Sicherheit als Import zu betrachten ist, kann zumindest nicht ausgeschlossen werden, dass die Uhr als Fertigstück nach Eretria kam. Es scheint daher sinnvoller, eine Herstellung der Uhr in Eretria und für Eretria zu postulieren. Dafür sprechen auch die nur sehr summarisch bearbeitete Rückseite und die deutlich von der ansonsten rechteckigen Gesamtform des Blockes abweichende Linienführung der Vorderseite. Dies scheint darauf hinzuweisen, dass die Sonnenuhr ursprünglich in einen architektonischen Zusammenhang eingegliedert war, was im übrigen auch für die Kegelsonnenuhr von Patras angenommen wurde.
df_descr.486: An der Peripherie der Platte sind drei fast konzentrische Kurven, mit den in Zwischenräumen von 47 mm gestellten Zahlzeichen VII-XI, eingegraben; zentrales, rundes Loch zur Aufnahme des stiftförmigen Sonnen- oder Schattenzeigers „gnomon“.
df_descr.487: The surviving part is a portion of the right half of the sundial (see figure). The oblique front forms an angle of 33° with the rear vertical plane, very different from the latitude of Nepi, which is about 42°. The noon hour line is almost completely missing. The hour lines from VII to XI and parts of the winter solstice and equinox curves are present. The remaining segments of the day curves are of equal length: 22 mm on the winter solstice curve, 35 mm on the equinox, and 64 mm on the circular intersection with the oblique front cut.  Because of the few elements available it is difficult to make any reliable calculations or any evaluation of how accurate this sundial may have been.
df_descr.488: It was possible to measure the angle between the oblique front and the rear vertical plane, which is about 42°, consistent with that of Torre Flavia. In spite of its poor state, three hour lines and two winter solstice and equinox arcs are still visible (see figure).
df_descr.489: The absence of much of the noon hour line makes the usual calculations difficult. By a fairly easy reconstruction, however, the summer solstice curve gives an intended latitude of 32° while the winter solstice curve gives one of 34°. Both are very far from that of the site where the sundial was found, which is 42°. The angle between the oblique front and the rear vertical plane, which is 35°, shows the same discrepancy, but agrees quite closely with the calculated latitude. There are eleven hour lines, with hour-points satisfactorily equidistant, while the solstice curves are almost equidistant from the equinox line – 95 mm and 101 mm respectively. From an analysis of the sum of the data measured and calculated, this sundial seems to be well cut but not without constructional irregularities.
df_descr.490: It is an example of the rare case where the conical surface is cut quite perfectly, but all the geometrical details were added with poor accuracy. Accordingly, an ideal cone can be fitted with a half-aperture of 24° and an axis inclined at 22° to the cut horizontal bottom plane and the top plane of the piece. The deviation of this inclination from the local latitude of 33° is still more evident if one considers the 17° by which the oblique southern front plane is inclined to the vertical, thus differing by 5° from the perpendicular to the axis. Furthermore, the only inscribed curve (see figure) intersecting the eleven hour lines defines a plane even closer to the vertical and so this by no means represents a seasonal day line. No explanation can be offered for this other than that we have an imitation of such a line (or of an auxiliary one according to Hüttig's general interpretation). All the angles mentioned are uncertain by about ±2°, mainly due to the loss of reference accuracy because the southern shoulders of the piece have been broken off. Another oddity may be seen in the fact that the joining point of the eleven hour lines lies considerably below the upper edge of the surface, where no trace of a gnomon-mounting is visible. A gnomon at that level would be geometrically acceptable but it would interfere with the reading of the first and last daily hours, while a gnomon at a higher level would avoid this problem but would impair the accuracy at any hour.
df_descr.491: L’oggetto conserva poco più della metà della superfi cie concava sulla quale sono state incise le linee orarie. Delle undici linee orarie che dovevano dividere la meridiana in dodici parti (le ore temporarie in uso nel mondo greco e romano descritte nell’introduzione) se ne vedono solo cinque, tra cui quella del mezzodì. Sono ben visibili le linee dei solstizi e degli equinozi, che attraversano le linee orarie: come di consueto in questo tipo di manufatti la curva del solstizio d’estate coincide con il bordo lavorato dell’oggetto. L’alloggio delle linee orarie è stato realizzato in modo sferico. Nella parte inferiore si nota il taglio della pietra che, in questo tipo di manufatti costruiti ad arte, corrisponde alla latitudine del luogo. Dallo studio del reperto (Fig. 4) appare una inclinazione che collocherebbe la meridiana ad una latitudine di circa 37°, non compatibile con il luogo del rinvenimento o, in generale, con la fascia del centro Italia, ma con l’area del Sud Italia o della Grecia.
df_descr.501: The quarter sphere of Sundial 2 has suffered much greater damage than that of Sundial 3, but there are on its surface lines enough to indicate that the pattern originally inscribed thereon was a mirror image of that already described for Sundial 3. Damage to the stone has caused the loss of the exact location of the gnomon at each end as well as the method of their attachment. They were probably fixed perpendicular to the plane represented by the back of the limestone block at or near points X and Y where the radiate lines converge in each sundial. On each of the concave surfaces of Sundial 2 and Sundial 3 half of the dial pattern found on the reclining surface of Sundial 1 had been scribed except that the enumeration of the hours was reversed.
df_descr.505: Lead fill remains in the gnomon hole at the top of the dial. Three day curves are divided unevenly by eleven hour lines. A simple engraved design decorates the oblique front surface. Below the design, a rolled scroll molding fills the angle between the simple base and the oblique front.
df_descr.530: Undici linee orarie temporarie sono incise con buona precisione nella  parte alta della cavità sferica, delimitate dalle due curve solstiziali,  invernale quella superiore ed estiva quella inferiore. L’orologio si  presenta rotto ed incompleto nella parte superiore a sinistra  dell’impianto dello gnomone mancante, dove si riesce ad intravedere una  parte dell’incavo in cui era inserito; maggiormente danneggiata nella  parte anteriore sinistra e in parte di quella destra. Manca la linea  equinoziale.
df_descr.531: Questa bella meridiana sferica, con la caratteristica rottura delle  punte frontali esterne del blocco di pietra in cui è incisa, si mostra  molto simile a quella trovata sul dosso del Muscolo a Roma e poi  conservata per qualche tempo nel Museo Kircheriano. E’ semplice nella  realizzazione, ma di buona fattura per quanto riguarda il tracciato  orario. Riconoscibili 11 linee orarie e tre linee diurne per gli  equinozi ed i solstizi. Queste si trovano equidistanti tra loro, come  per le meridiane emisferiche. Caratteristica rara è il prolungamento di  tutte le linee orarie al di sotto della curva del solstizio estivo e  delle linee orarie 3 e 9 oltre la curva del solstizio invernale, come  per sottolinearne un’importanza maggiore rispetto alle altre linee  orarie. E’ visibile il foro in cui era alloggiato lo gnomone  orizzontale.
df_descr.535: lower part of dialface preserved, short distances between 4th and 6th hour line, hour lines intersect equniox day curve, lower edge of dialface presumbably winter solistice day curve,
df_descr.536: Seven hour lines preserved, no day curves, dialface takes up one third of sundial height, similarities with hispanic Rubi, according to Jenny's calculations the sundial was constructed for the latitude of Bregenz.
df_descr.537: Dialface takes up two third of sundial height. Dialface shaped irregular and concave. 11 hour lines and 2 day curves.
df_descr.538: Left side of dialface preserved. Regular distances between 1st and 6th hour line. Presumably no specifc dialface type.
df_descr.539: Well preserved sundial, parts broke off at the lower edge of dialface. 11 hour lines, 3 day curves.
df_descr.540: Small sundial, no decor, dialface takes up two third of sundial height. 11 hour lines, 3 day curves.
df_descr.541: Part of dialface preserved.Two hour lines and three day curves
df_descr.542: Fragment of a big sundial, part of dialface preserved, 5 hour lines, winter and summer solistice day curves. Hour lines wider in upper part of dial.
df_descr.544: Conical sundial takes up one half of sundial's height. Roughened surface might hint at cornices.
df_descr.545: Horizontal sundial carved in the paved surface of the local forum.
df_descr.546: Big sundial composed of three fitting fragments. Broken at upper part of dialface. Hour lines 3 to 10 discernible, between summer and winter solistice day curve, Only Meridian has been extended until Gnomon. Dialface takes up two third of sundial height. Probably colored and plastered with cornices.
df_descr.547: Small fragment of spherical sundial. Lower edge of dialface, contains 2 hour lines and 2 day curves.
df_descr.548: According to Dyggve's sketch, the sundial is composed of two fitting fragments. Dialface divided into 11 hour lines. No day curves on sketch. Sundial put up in the sanctuary
df_descr.549: Fragment of spherical sundial that broke off at the right side. Morning hour lines regularly. One day curve.
df_descr.550: Dialface takes up one third of sundial. Only short parts of hour lines discernible. Dialface embraced by wide limbo.
df_descr.553: Tiny fragment of conical sundial made of local limestone.
df_descr.554: Upper right edge of conical sundial preserved. Parts of 8th and 9th hour line, two day curves. Inscription refers to manufacturer.
df_descr.555: Uncertain whether sundial exists. According to B. Weber it was part of the site of Heroon B.
df_descr.556: Probably from same workshop as ObjID555. Dialface taks up two third of sundial. Left side broke off. Hour lines 5 to 10 discernible, 3 day curves . Meridian extended beyond summer solistice day curve.
df_descr.557: Left side of sundial preserved including 6 hour lines. Two more framents that according to Orlando belong to ObjID555. 2 day curves preserved.
df_descr.558: Damaged fragment in Berlin contains afternoon side of dialface, 6th to 9th hour line, 2 day curves. Dialface encompassed by 2 cm wide limbo.
df_descr.559: Afternoon side of sundial preserved including 7th to 11th hour line plus winter solistice and equinox day curve. Right edge of dialface damaged.
df_descr.560: Dialface takes up more than two third of sundial height. Dialface divided into 11 hour lines and two day curves.
df_descr.561: Dialface takes up upper half of sundial height. Dialface divided into 11 hour lines and 3 day curves. Letters fragments at day curves hint at an original inscription.
df_descr.562: Dialface contains irregularly placed 11 hour lines. Hour lines reach up to gnomon hole.
df_descr.563: Presumably a sundial because three sections of hour lines are discernible. Heavily damaged fragment, maybe spherical sundial.
df_descr.564: Horizontal sundial heavily damaged. Five lines discernible at lower right edge. Lines radiate from a midpoint and end at a line that forms a semi-circle.
df_descr.565: A horizontal sundial has been sketchly curved into the upper bed of a rectangular course. Sundial probably used secondarly.
df_descr.566: One fourth of dialface of sundial preserved. Embraced by a wide limbo, According to Valev, spherical type.
df_descr.567: Well preserved sundial, light damage along the edge of the dialface. Dialface carefully smoothed and divided into 11 hour lines
df_descr.568: Only right side of dialface preserved; 6th to 11th hour line. 3 day curves discernible.
df_descr.569: Well preserved sundial, dialface includes 11 hour lines and 3 day curves. All lines are equally deep, wide and linear.
df_descr.570: Sundial broke off at left side and right end of dialface. Originally divided into 11 hour lines and 2 day curves. It seems that the dialface is embraced by a limbo.
df_descr.571: Horizontal sundial curved into the forum of Timgad. Sections of four vertical afternoon hour lines preserved, hours 7 to 10.
df_descr.592: In den Aufzeichnungen von Albert Rehm heißt es: „1905: Stück einer Säule von bläulichem Marmor. Im Felde beim Thor der heiligen Straße. H. 0,68, Durchm. 0,47: … sicher röm. Kaiserzeit.“ Rehm ist über den Fund zunächst so erstaunt, dass er die 31cm lange Mittagslinie zunächst  als belanglos ansieht und nie über sie publiziert. Erst viel später, am 4.2.1939, notiert er: „Es ist doch mehr als Spielerei, wie ich s. Z. glaubte, ein Hilfsmittel, den Mittagsschatten zu beobachten, um danach die Wasseruhr zu regulieren.“
df_descr.593: Es wurden nur Teile der Inschrift zur Uhr wurden 1901 am See Mariut nahe bei Alexandria (Ägypten) entdeckt.
df_descr.601: Fragment with one hour line and one date line
df_descr.602: Fragment with three hour lines and one date line.
df_descr.611: Hohlkegel mit Inschrift; Bruchstück,  used secondarly
df_descr.616: Sundial which stood on  a pedestal and bears an inscription: Τιβ(έριος) Κλαύδιος [Π]ολυπείθης ἐκ το̑ν ἰδίων ἀνέθηκεν. Tiberius Claudius Polypeithes hat (diese Uhr) auf eigene Kosten  aufgestellt. When an earthquake levelled the citiy in the senth century the column collapsed and broke in two and the sundial in seven pieces.
df_descr.619: Lions feet and an inscription stating that it was "erutum in agro Veliterno"
df_descr.622: Fragment of a conical (?) dial. Remarkable is a sculptured eagle on the base of the dial.
df_descr.624: Probably hellenstic dial bearing an inscription
df_descr.625: Hollowed dial above the head of a bull; inscription  on the shadow receiving surface.
df_descr.633: At the back of the limestone block two spaces, each in the shape of a quarter sphere, one at either end of the block, have been hollowed out of the stone (figs. 3, 5a, 5b; photograph 2). The vertical axes of these quarter spheres are the intersections of a vertical plane representing the back of the limestone block and the two vertical planes representing the ends of the block. Damage in the past has caused the loss of between 1/3 and 1/2 of each of the 24 cm diameter quarter spheres and the loss of almost all of the lines and numerals once inscribed on their concave surfaces (figs. 4 and 6, photographs 2, 3 and 4). The quarter sphere to the right as one faces the back of the limestone block, Sundial 3 (figs. 4, 5b and 6, photographs 2 and 4), has on its extant surface the remains of five inscribed lines, all of which radiate from point Y at the edge of the quarter sphere. Point Y may be defined as that place on the concave surface of the quarter sphere of Sundial 3 where the vertical plane representing the end of the limestone block and a horizontal plane parallel to and 17 cm above the plane representing the bottom surface of the limestone block intersect (fig. 5b). All five scribed lines radiate at equal angles and divide the lower and larger segment of the surface of the quarter sphere into six sectors. These six sectors and the lines which define them are in turn intersected by three lines approximately 5 cm apart. The three equidistant intersecting lines can perhaps best be visualized as intersections on the quarter spherical surface by three parallel planes 5 cm apart, all inclined at an angle of 33" from the vertical. These three planes, therefore, are parallel to the reclined plane represented by the surface of Sundial 1.
df_descr.638: West-facing part: As many as seven day curves cross the four preserved hour lines on both faces. [...]  Remaining inscription is difficult to decipher. A segment of the equinoctial line between hour points is 39 mm long.
df_descr.641: Ante meridian part. At the top left corner of the dial, above the left meridian, there is a gnomon hole containing some trace of lead fill. The shadow-receiving surface of this dial is essentially that of a section of truncated cone which has been split at the meridian and transposed before being cut into the stone. Rather than continuing smoothly to the top of the dial, the conical surface is cut off above the winter solstice by a rough protrusion on each side. Six hour lines, including the meridian, are crossed by three day curves within each dial half.  The summer solstice is distinct from the lower edge, but the winter curve is marked only by the junction of the smooth conical surface with the rough protrusion. The center front surface of the dial has been decorated with a relief showing a priestly figure wearing a polos and a flowing robe, reaching for the tendrils of a symmetrically framing plant.
df_descr.643: Die sechs erhaltenen Stücke sind wieder zusammengefügt und ergeben eine 2-5 cm dicke Marmorplatte, die auf jeder Seite ein Liniennetz mit ähnlichem Aussehen trägt, nämlich Halbkreisbögen, die durch gerade, zu den hypothetischen Mittelpunkten führende Linien in gleiche Sektoren unterteilt sind. Die Linien sind fein, meist sauber gezogen und haben eine gleich bleibende Breite von etwa 1 mm. Der Stein ist im Bereich der großen Kreisbögen ein wenig gekrümmt. Die eine Fläche trägt eine nur noch teilweise erhaltene Inschrift. Auf ihr verlaufen die Strahlen bis unterhalb des Gnomonkanals, wo sie von einem kleinen Kreisbogen mit einem Radius von ca. 25 mm begrenzt werden. Ihre Verlängerungen treffen sich über der Kante. Auf der gegenüberliegenden Fläche, wo die Linien etwas stärker verwittert sind, gehen sie, zuletzt aber mit unklarer Führung, bis zum Gnomonkanal. Die Radien der beiden großen Kreise betragen auf beiden Seiten 294 mm. Der Gnomonkanal ist durchgängig, das heißt, der ursprüngliche Gnomon ragte beiderseits über die Schattenflächen hinaus. Sein Befestigungsloch wurde vom Gnomonkanal in den dünnen Stein hinein gemeißelt. Der Gnomonkanal verläuft schräg zum Stein und damit parallel zur oberen und zur unteren Kante. Der Neigungswinkel der Kanten zur Vertikalen hat einen Wert von etwa 40°, die Ortsbreite für das Amphiareion beträgt 38°19'. Der Stein ist im Bereich der Tagundnachtgleichen etwas dicker und der Gnomon ist auf beiden Seiten so kurz gehalten, dass die Schatten an den Äquinoktien die großen kreisförmigen Datumslinien treffen konnten. Auf der Winterseite, der Inschriftseite, lief der Schatten vom großen Kreisbogen des Herbstäquinoktiums zum kleinen Kreisbogen des Wintersolstitiums, wieder zurück zum Frühjahrsäquinoktium, um dann auf die Sommerseite hinüber zu wechseln, wo er vom Frühjahrsäquinoktium bis zum Herbstäquinoktium blieb.
df_descr.644: North face. This configuration of lines closely ressembles that on the concave surface of a roofed spherical variant dial. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are visible. A shallow hole marks the meeting point of the three day curves.
df_descr.645: Right upper corner destroyed. Eleven hourlines and two daycurves, a third one probably broken off or ending in the lower edge of the shadow area.
df_descr.646: Lower south face. Three great circles meet at the east and west poles. Eleven cross lines extend between the first and second great circles. Thirteen cross lines extend between the second and third great circles.Shallow holes mark the east and west points and the junction of horizone and meridian.
df_descr.661: at the eastern side, three lines and traces of a gnomon are visible
df_descr.664: western part of the front dial that is put together from two plane surfaces, antemeridial hours
df_descr.665: eastern part of the front dial that is put together from two plane surfaces, postmeridial hours
