obj_descr.207: The gnomon hole at the left side is 8 mm in diameter. It slants downward at an angle 45 from the horizontal. The right gnomon hole is lead filled. The transposed halves of a dished conical surface form the shadow-receiving area of this dial. The sagitta at the left equinox is about  8 mm; at right, 9 mm. Six hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on each side. The base is a schematic lion´s paw.
obj_descr.208: The unique shape of this dial face is shown in the adjoining meridian section. The surface is conical, possibly a complete right circular cone. The vertex of the conical surface is carved out of the stone. Its position is marked by a shallow, square, depression which contains no metal. The generator of the conical surface is horizontal at the meridian. Seven preserved hour lines, containing traces of black coloring, cross three day curves, but do not extend beyond either solstice. The day curves do not seem to be parallel to each other, and certainly the summer solstice is not always equidistant from the lower edge.
obj_descr.209: Die rechte Hälfte des Uhrenkörpers fehlt. Die Linien sind relativ breit und tief. Eine Sommerwendlinie ist nicht vorhanden. Die Stundenlinien enden an einem gerundeten, stark vorkragenden Limbus, wie er bei Sonnenuhren der rhodischen Form vorkommt. Auf der linken Seite ist der Ansatz eines Fußes erkennbar. Im Uhrenkörper unterhalb der abgebrochenen Deckfläche liegen zwei  7 mm breite Befestigungslöcher, welche wohl für den Gnomon bestimmt waren.
obj_descr.210: Die Schattenfläche ist entweder kegelförmig oder zylindrisch. Eine Sommerwendlinie ist nicht eingemeißelt. Da außerdem ein großer Teil der Schattenfläche fehlt, ist nicht zu erkennen, ob andere Datumslinien vorhanden waren. Die Stundenlinien enden noch vor dem unteren Rand der Schattenfläche und halten dort einen Abstand von etwa 35 mm voneinander. Seitenflächen und Rückwand sind geebnet.
obj_descr.211: 11 Stundenlinien und zwei Datumslinien. Die Stundenlinien der kleinen Uhr sind gleichmäßig vertieft, die Sommerwendlinie fehlt. Die Winterwendlinie wurde als Kreis um den Gnomonfußpunkt gezeichnet, weshalb sie nicht parallel zur Äquinoktiallinie liegt. Dadurch vergrößert sich ihr Abstand voneinander zu den Randstunden hin. Die beiden Randstunden sind breiter als die übrigen Stunden. Auch ist dort die Krümmung der Schattenfläche nicht mehr konisch. In der Deckfläche befinden sich zwei Gnomonlöcher, das eine ist nach vorne hin ausgebrochen, in dem anderen sind Spuren von Blei. Die Vorderfläche ist eben, nur zwischen den dreizehigen Löwentatzen ist ein flacher Limbus von 2 cm Breite ausgebildet.
obj_descr.212: 11 Stundenlinien und drei Datumslinien. Die Schattenfläche der Uhr, die aus drei Bruchstücken wieder zusammengefügt ist, weitet sich zum Betrachter hin wie eine Kegelsonnenuhr und zur Deckfläche hin wie eine Hohlkugelsonnenuhr. Die Vorderfläche steht fast senkrecht, so dass sich das Bild einer Viertelkugel ergibt. Die Achse der Datumlinien ist horizontal ausgerichtet. Alle Linien sind sehr grob gezogen. Die Segmente für die Morgen- und Abendstunden sind breiter als bei den anderen Stunden. Die Pseudodatumslinie, die etwa 1 cm Abstand vom unteren Rand der Schattenfläche hält, ist nicht vollständig erhalten. In der Deckfläche verläuft eine 25 mm lange Rinne für einen metallenen Gnomon, dessen Befestigungsloch sich auf der geebneten Rückseite befindet. Auf der Basis umgrenzen Füße zwei voneinander abgeteilte Felder, die beschriftet sind.
obj_descr.213: 11 feine Stundenlinien und drei Datumslinien. Geringe Teile der Deckfläche von der Schattenfläche sind abgebrochen. Der gerundete Gnomonkanal ist 9 mm tief, 14 mm breit und 32 mm lang. Rötliche Spuren einer Oxydation verlaufen ausgehend von der Halterung über die Schattenfläche. Die Basis ist schmucklos, wölbt sich konvex im oberen Teil und geht dann lotrecht nach unten.
obj_descr.214: Die Stundenlinien (4 bis 11, keine Datumslinie) verlaufen in einem exakten Abstand voneinander und sind gleichmäßig vertieft. 16 mm vor dem unteren Rand der Schattenfläche kreuzt ein kurzer Strich die Mittagslinie. Die Abstände der Stundenlinien auf Höhe des Querstrichs betragen jeweils 34 mm. Die Neigung der Vorderfläche passt zu Thessaloniki. Der Limbus hat eine Breite von 16 mm. Zwei naturgetreu gearbeitete Löwenfüße zeichnen den Fund aus.
obj_descr.215: Die Stundenlinien (11, zwei Datumslinien) sind gleichmäßig vertieft, aber nur ungenau ausgearbeitet. Die Sommerwendlinie fehlt. Locher führte ihr Fehlen darauf zurück, dass der vordere Teil der Schattenfläche abgebrochen sei. Das ist nicht nachzuvollziehen: nur die Enden sind abgebrochen. Ein Limbus von 22-25 mm Breite umgrenzt die Schattenfläche. In der Deckfläche ist eine v-förmige Vertiefung für einen schmalen metallenen Gnomon, auf der nur grob gearbeiteten Rückwand ist ein Befestigungsloch zu erkennen. Die Basis ist abgebrochen.
obj_descr.216: 6 Stundenlinien (3 bis 8) und zwei Datumslinien. Die Sommerwendlinie fehlt.  Die Uhr ist aus zwei Bruchstücken wieder zusammengesetzt. Auf der Schattenfläche ist in schwarzer Farbe eine alte Inventarnummer (E377) aufgemalt. Die rückseitig gerundete Uhr ruht auf einer vierzehigen, etwa 100 mm hohen Löwentatze.
obj_descr.217: 9 Stundenlinien (2 bis 10, keine Datumslinie) wurden in eine Viertel-Hohlkugel (Radius 95-105 mm) grob eingemeißelt. Die Randsektoren sind etwas breiter und stehen offenbar für je zwei Morgen- und Abendstunden, was eine 10-teilige Schattenfläche ergibt. Die Stundenlinien haben einen unregelmäßigen Abstand voneinander und verlaufen vom Fußpunkt des Gnomons zum unteren Rand der Schattenfläche. Eine 35 mm lange und sehr flache, zweigeteilte Gnomonrinne halbiert die Deckfläche. Basis und Befestigungslöcher fehlen.
obj_descr.218: Die Uhr hat 11 Stundenlinien und zwei Datumslinien. Die Schattenfläche ist nur schwach gewölbt. Sie weist Verletzungen durch eine Baggerschaufel auf sowie das Fehlen größere Teile auf der linken Seite. Die Stundenlinien sind relativ breit (2 mm) und scharf gezogen. Eine Sommerwendlinie fehlt. Die beiden vorhandenen Datumslinien neigen sich nach innen (Pseudodatumslinien). In der Deckfläche befindet sich ein Gnomonloch (Weite 300 mm x 30 mm, Tiefe 20 mm) und eine schmale Gnomonrinne. An den beiden Seitenflächen der Basis sieht man zwei Fischreliefs (eintauchende Delphine?) über einer 25 mm hohen Bodenplatte. Zwischen den Fischköpfen auf der Vorderseite liegt ein freies, etwa 155 mm x 60 mm großes Feld. Die Bodenfläche ist ohne Dübelloch.
obj_descr.219: 10 Stundenlinien (1 bis 10) und zwei Datumslinien, relativ breit (bis 2 mm). Die Schattenfläche ist für die Abendstunden ganz abgebrochen. Die zehnte Stundenlinie ist nur noch ansatzweise erkennbar. Eine Sommerwendlinie fehlt. Die Mittagslinie geht als einzige Stundenlinie über die Winterwendlinie hinaus bis zum Gnomonloch. Bleireste (25 mm x 25 mm) bedecken das Gnomonloch, das für einen schmalen, flachen Gnomon gearbeitet war. Ein etwa 20 mm breiter, im Mittelteil allerdings nicht durchgehender Limbus trennt die Schattenfläche von der Basis. Die Reste eines Reliefs schließen sich an, das einen Fischschwarm darstellt. Die Rückwand ist gerundet. Die Basis ist abgebrochen.
obj_descr.220: Traces of iron gnomon remain in gnomon hole 13 mm in diameter. Meridian and equinox line divide the shadow-receiving surface into four equal rectangles. The usual eleven hour line/three day curve grid has been modified to include two straight lines which radiate from the point of intersection of meridian and winter solstice at angles of 25 (left) and 24 (right).
obj_descr.221: The iron gnomon, now broken off at the base, is held in place by a lead adhesive. A permanent glass covering makes modern measurement impossible. The figures at left were obtained from Grablovitz´ early publication and recent photographs. These researched and calculated results compare favorably with measurements taken from a plaster cast of the dial displayed in the Museo della Civitá romana.  The windrose surrounding the dial is inscribed in Latin Both inscriptions, the eleven hour lines and three day curves are emphasized by a black coloring which may not be original.
obj_descr.222: Traces of three hour lines, equinox, and one solstice remain on this dial fragment. It is possible that the bottom edge follows the curve of the other solstice. A red 392 has been painted on the back of the dial.
obj_descr.223: The base of a bronze gnomon, 12 mm wide, remains in a lead-filled hole. Two round holes at the left side of the dial block may have served for mounting. Meridian and equinox divide the shadow-receiving surface into four rectangles. The grid of eleven hour lines and three day curves may have been determind by the dots which mark the junctions of hour lines and solstices.
obj_descr.224: The core of the gnomon hole, containing no metal, is visible in the center of a large circular scarred area along the meridian above the summer solstice. This dial has been carved on the horizontal section of a column 43 cm in diameter. The grid of lines includes eleven hour lines and three day curves. The points of intersection of hour lines and solstices are marked by dots. The meridian extends beyond winter and summer solstices to the edges of the section.
obj_descr.227: A trace of gnomon hole is preserved along the broken right edge which coincides with the meridian of the dial. No metal remains. Three fragments have been joined to form the left half of a sundial. The equinox crosses and extends a little beyond the six preserved hour lines. Winter and summer solstice curves have been approximated by straight lines. The meridian extends beyond both solstices the length of the diameter of the inner circle.
obj_descr.228: Both these marble fragments seem to be parts of the same dial although the two pieces are of different thicknesses.
obj_descr.229: One side of this flat stone is inscribed with part of a sundial and wind rose. The solstices, equinox, and signs of the zodiac are identified in Latin. The reverse side of the stone is inscribed as a gameboard.
obj_descr.230: Catamo: The usual parameters  give a latitude of 45° (Tivoli is at 42°) and a perpendicular height for the gnomon of 36 mm. The directions and the distances measured from the projection of the gnomon point on the plane at the extremities of the hour lines on the three day curves (see figure) show discrepancies, albeit not large ones, from those obtained by calculation. As a whole, it seems to be a sundial of average accuracy. When it was first discovered, traces of lead and iron were found in the hole for the gnomon, which was some way from the correct position, suggesting that the rod was bent or curved so that its tip would be in the right position. At some time - it is impossible to know exactly when, but certainly after the discovery - a strongly curved iron gnomon was fixed in it with lead, but this is out of square.
obj_descr.231: A stump of iron gnomon remains in position. The fragment is approximately half a dial with seven hour lines (5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11) and three day curves preserved. The meridian extends from the top of the fragment to some distance beyond the winter solstice.
obj_descr.232: Parts of eight hour lines are preserved on this triangular fragment (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10). Complete hour lines do not extend beyond solstices, but meridian does continue beyond these bounds. Solstice curves seem to be approximate; equinox and hour lines are creditably straight. At the junction of meridian and engraved lower border of the fragment an interesting group of engraved lines is visible. It consists of two straight lines intersecting the meridian in the same point at angles of 24 on the left and 22 on the right. In addition, two engraved circles with centers can be seen on either side of the meridian tangent to these straight lines and the meridian.
obj_descr.233: The round gnomon hole, 8 mm in diameter, contains traces of bronze and iron. A hole for possible mounting is visible in the back at top center. The stone is shaped like a truncated pyramid with the dial engraved on the base with the larger surface area. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are visible. Lines for the fifth and seventh hours split into two lines just below the equinox.
obj_descr.235: Gibbs: The equinox is a horizontal straight line as it should be for all latitudes between equator and pole. As plane sections of sunlight cones, the day curves should be parts of hyperbolas for latitudes above the torrid zone. The curve closest to the projection of the gnomon point on the vertical face is that traced by the shadow of the gnomon point on winter solstice. The day curve at winter solstice is limited by a horizontal line passing through the projection of the gnomon point. In spring and summer, the shadow of a gnomon point will fall on a south-facing vertical dial for only part of the day. An additional north-facing vertical dial with its own gnomon point is required for marking some of the seasonal hours between the spring and autumn equinox. It seems likely that the designer of the south (and north) face of the Tower of Winds determind the pattern of hour lines and day curves by constructing seasonal hour points on the dial face and joining them. The Ptolemaic coordinates relevant to the construction of prime vertical sundials are the vertical and horarius arcs. (p. 43) If the vertical dials on the eight sides of Andronicus' Tower of Winds in Athens were engraved at the time the tower was built, they belong to the first century B.C. (p.78 f) Some time during the first century B.C. Andronicus Cyrrhestes designed and built an octagonal tower on which eight planar sundials are visible today (see Vitruvius, De architectura I, 6.4). The dials face the principal points of the compass. (p. 342)  Schaldach: Achteckiges Gebäude. Unter einem flachen Pyramidendach befinden sich durch ihre Namen gekennzeichnet - die Reliefs der Windgötter, männliche geflügelte Wesen, die sich dem Betrachter im Halbprofil zuwenden. Darunter ist auf jeder Wand über ihre gesamte Breite das Liniennetz einer Vertikaluhr aufgetragen. Der Bau ist, mit einer Höhe von13,5 m und einer Wandbreite von 3,3 m auf jeder Seite, über einer dreistufigen Krepis äußerst präzise nach den Himmelsrichtungen orientiert. An der NO- und NW-Seite sind die beiden Eingänge mit kurzen rechteckigen Portikus. Von den drei kleinen Fenstern auf der N-, W- und S-Seite ist keines original. Kernstück der Inneneinrichtung war eine Wasseruhr, von der nur mehr das innere Becken und die Zu- und Ablaufrinnen erkennbar sind.
obj_descr.236: Gibbs: The equinox is a horizontal straight line as it should be for all latitudes between equator and pole. (p.78 f) Some time during the first century B.C. Andronicus Cyrrhestes designed and built an octagonal tower on which eight planar sundials are visible today (see Vitruvius, De architectura I, 6.4). The dials face the principal points of the compass. (p. 342)  Schaldach: Achteckiges Gebäude. Unter einem flachen Pyramidendach befinden sich durch ihre Namen gekennzeichnet - die Reliefs der Windgötter, männliche geflügelte Wesen, die sich dem Betrachter im Halbprofil zuwenden. Darunter ist auf jeder Wand über ihre gesamte Breite das Liniennetz einer Vertikaluhr aufgetragen. Der Bau ist, mit einer Höhe von13,5 m und einer Wandbreite von 3,3 m auf jeder Seite, über einer dreistufigen Krepis äußerst präzise nach den Himmelsrichtungen orientiert. An der NO- und NW-Seite sind die beiden Eingänge mit kurzen rechteckigen Portikus. Von den drei kleinen Fenstern auf der N-, W- und S-Seite ist keines original. Kernstück der Inneneinrichtung war eine Wasseruhr, von der nur mehr das innere Becken und die Zu- und Ablaufrinnen erkennbar sind.

obj_descr.244: The position and measurements of the gnomon holes are shown in the accompanying diagram. No metal remains. This dial is a combination of four deviating vertical dials. On all faces, the hour lines have been engraved less heavily than the day curves. The equinox appears to have been engraved last.

On all faces, the hour lines have been engraved less heavily than the day curves. The equinox appears to have been engraved last.

obj_descr.248: Gibbs: Eleven scratched hour lines are connected by two semi-circles at the top and bottom; hour lines do not extend beyond curved boundaries. The left edge is finished smoothly at the top and bears a trace of curved molding. With the help of a strong light it is possible to see scratched Greek letters near the outer circle. Schaldach: Die unregelmäßigen Stundenlinien erstrecken sich zwischen zwei konzentrischen halbkreisförmigen Linien mit Radien von etwa 20,5 cm und 3 cm. Der Fund ist nach allen Seiten hin abgebrochen, deshalb ist der große Halbkreis nur zum Teil vorhanden. Der kleine Halbkreis ist schwach ausgebildet. Er wird von einigen Stundenlinien gekreuzt, deren Verlängerungen sich nicht in einem gemeinsamen Punkt reffen, weshalb keine genauen Stundenwinkel angegeben werden können. Innerhalb der Sektoren und in der Nähe der äußeren Kreislinie sind noch Reste der Buchstaben A, B und G zur Benennung der Stunden zu erkennen.
obj_descr.249: Gibbs: Seven hour lines, meeting at a hole at the top, and joined by a broken line resembling a quarter circle at the bottom, form this dial grid. A scraped area to the right of the meridian may indicate either preparation for the completion of the dial or destruction of part of the grid. Broneer remarks that the ruined odium at Corinth was used for private dwellings in the third and fourth centuries A.D.; the scratched dial probably dates from this period. The hour lines measure from left to right: 125 mm, 119 mm, 118 mm, 122 mm, 119 mm, 125 mm, 130 mm. These hour lines form the following angles, measure from left to right: 15.5, 14.5, 13, 10.5, 14, 15.5.  Schaldach: Die 6 Stundenlinien in einem leicht geglätteten Bereich des Steins haben eine Länge von etwa 130 mm und treffen sich etwas unterhalb des Gnomonlochs. Die umgrenzten fünf Sektoren haben Winkelgrößen von (ab Mittagslinie gemessen): 18, 14, 11, 14; 14.  Bei der von Gibbs genannten siebten Stundenlinie handelt es sich vermutlich um eine nur angedeutete Linie im Feld der ersten Stunde. Die Fläche ist nicht genau nach Süden orientiert, sondern weicht leicht nach Osten ab. Die Uhr ist erst entstanden, nachdem die Gänge zu den Zuschauerräumen zerstört und die Schattenfläche der Sonne am Vormittag ausgesetzt war. Der Verfall des Odeons begann im 2. Jh., vom 3. Jh. Bis  ins 5.Jh. sind private Nutzungen nachgewiesen (Broneer, S. 140).
obj_descr.250: Gibbs: A gnomon hole 18 mm square and 18 mm deep is preserved in the top surface of the dial above the meridian. Its sides are oriented parallel to and perpendicular to the sloping edge which intersects the edge of the dial surface at an angle of 142.8. A slight depression leads from this hole towards the sloping edge. There is no metal in the hole or the groove. Three fragments have been joined to form this southwest facing dial surface. The finished left edge of the slab is formed by a sloping surface which intersects the dial surface at an angle of 142.8. Top and bottom edges are smoothly finished and a section of the right edge smoothly follows the curve of the summer solstice. Five engraved hour lines have been preserved in addition to the meridian which is formed by the intersecting planes of the left edge. Three day curves extend from the meridian to the top edge. Two clamp holes and grooves are preserved in the rough picked back along the unbroken meridian edge.  Schaldach: Die vertikale SW-Uhr ist aus drei Teilen wieder zusammengefügt und zeigt eine fast vollständig erhaltene Schattenfläche für die Nachmittagsstunden. Die Stundenlinien sind gleichmäßig tief und breit gezogen. Die Kantenfläche, welche mit der Vorderfläche die Mittagslinie formt, ist zweifach abgeschrägt. Der Neigungswinkel zur Schattenfläche beträgt 40 bis 45 bei einer Länge von etwa 68 mm. Die anschließende Schräge hat eine Länge von etwa 35 mm. Auf der grob behauenen Rückseite befinden sich entlang der Kantenlinie zwei Klammerlöcher. Die obere Kantenfläche ist gleichmäßig eben mit einem Loch unweit der Ecke von 18 mm Durchmesser und 18 mm Tiefe und bildet mit der Vorderfläche die Sonnenunterganglinie. Die zweite, zum großen Teil abgebrochene Seitenfläche zeigt den Rest einer gebogenen Kante. Glasers Überlegung, dass alle vier Wände, also auch die SO-Wand, die NO-Wand und die NW-Wand des Bauwerks eine Sonnenuhr besaßen, wird durch das Fragment einer SO-Uhr unterstützt, welches Gibbs im Amphiareion noch vorfand (5006G), aber weder durch Glaser in den Jahren 1973-78, noch durch mich in 2001 aufgefunden wurde. Die abgefaste Kante, im Winkel von 40-45, ist nicht so fein abgearbeitet wie die Schattenfläche mit den Linien.
obj_descr.251: Gibbs: This fragment is the upper left corner of a southeast-facing dial. Top and lower edges are finished smooth. Three engraved hour lines (1, 2, 3) and three day curves are preserved. All planes of the slab surface intersect at right angles.  Schaldach: Glasers Überlegung, dass alle vier Wände, also auch die SO-Wand, die NO-Wand und die NW-Wand des Bauwerks eine Sonnenuhr besaßen, wird durch das Fragment einer SO-Uhr unterstützt, welches Gibbs im Amphiareion noch vorfand (5006G), aber weder durch Glaser in den Jahren 1973-78, noch durch mich in 2001 aufgefunden wurde.
obj_descr.253: The base of a bronze gnomon in lead fill remains in the top surface above the meridian formed by the intersecting dial surfaces. This well-preserved dial consists of two dial surfaces, each with five engraved hour lines and three day curves, meeting at the meridian; one surface faces southeast, the other southwest. Some hour lines on the right extend beyond the summer solstice, but all seem to be contained within the winter curve.
obj_descr.254: The drawing in Deonna shows fourteen hour lines. Part of an engraved circular curve is visible at lower left. The hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole to the circular arc.
obj_descr.255: Three day curves and six hour lines (including horizon line) are visible.
obj_descr.256: A hole for a gnomon is preserved in the top of the dial directly above the meridian line; some residue of lead remains. A smooth curved edge on the right side follows the curve of the summer solstice. Five fairly deeply incised hour lines do not continue beyond either solstice curve. The right edge is finished in a double concave molding. There is no trace of color, relief decoration, or inscription. Gibbs's illustration is slightly distorted and differs from real object.
obj_descr.257: The combination of grooves at the top center of this dial block presumably held the gnomon. Eleven fairly deeply scratched hour lines divide a single semicircle into twelve parts on this dial. The shadow-receiving surface is uniformly thick and smoothly finished. The hour lines measure from left to right: 130, 131, 132, 132, 132, 130, 134, 135, 136, 135, 132 mm. They form the following angles, measured from the left to the right horizon: 10.8, 18, 15, 15.4, 15.8, 15, 12, 15.8, 16, 20.5, 16, 9.7.
obj_descr.258: Five deeply engraved hour lines, the equinox, and the winter solstices remain on this dial fragment. The meridian is not preserved.
obj_descr.259: Two preserved holes may have served separately or together as gnomon holders. One hole in the top of the dial is filled with lead and connected to the right edge by a groove 85 mm deep. A second hole, 10 mm wide, is situated 34 mm from the top along the right edge sloping up at an angle of 45. Six engraved hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on this southeast-facing half of a vertical deviating dial. The equinox and two solstices do not extend beyond the first hour line. Although the dial has been squared off along the left edge, a portion of the curved border remains. The top and right edge are smoothly perpendicular to the dial face. A large engraved B is preserved at the left end of the top edge. Evidence at the junctures of the wide hour lines and the equinox indicates that the former were engraved last.
obj_descr.261: Gibbs: The engraved lines on this dial face include five hour lines, the winter solstice, the equinox, and the summer solstice. The dial appears to have been made to face southeast.  Severino: Scheda del museo : N° 2 lastre di marmo bianco, centinate ad un quarto di cerchio da un lato con la parte in piano incisa con 5 segni messi nel senso dell’angolo a raggiungere l’altro segno fatto in modo da seguire la curva spezzata nella parte centrale e partente da un lato a raggiungere l’altro, tali incisioni sono 3, nello spessore delle lastre e cioè nell parte centinata ove vanno a convergere le linee vi sono dei segni fatti per misura m. 0,72 x 0.55 x 0.028. Spezzata in 13 frammenti. Provenienza Nemi (Valle Giardino). Entrata al museo in marzo-febbraio 1925. Ammissione Aprile 1931. Prezzo £. 50. Vecchia collocazione, Olearie, settore 19 A 2° ripiano. La descrizione è fatta ovviamente da una persona completamente estranea alla gnomonica ed all’astronomia in genere. E’ importante notare che la scheda cataloga in un unico numero di inventario, il 112134, due lastre di marmo che si crede appartenenti ad un unico reperto. In realtà le due lastre di marmo rappresentano due meridiane verticali declinanti complementari, ben distinte. Una occidua, l’altra ortiva. Alla seconda lastra che rappresenta la meridian occidua e che doveva essere posizionata a 90 gradi circa (ad angolo retto) con la presente, le daremo convenzionalmente e provvisoriamente il numero di inventario 112134 bis, per distinguerla dal primo reperto. Continuando con le annotazione, rileviamo che questa meridiana è stata pubblicata anche da Gibbs al numero del suo catalogo 5016 per la quale ripete quanto diceva già l’Antonini al numero 10 che era stata vista in Casa De Angelis a Tivoli. Fatto sta che al Museo ci è arrivata proveniente da Nemi.
obj_descr.262: Gibbs: Marucchi describes a configuration of four engraved lines which he suggests served to mark the positions of the third and ninth hours of the day between winter and summer solstice.   A.L.F.Jr.: This sun-dial was different from any hitherto known, in having not one but six gnomons, one for each hour, and consequently for each line, at the extremity of which it was placed; while in the centre there must have been a vertical one for mid-day. These metal styles threw their shadow down their line at the corresponding hour, but the correspondence was perfect only during equinoctial days. It would be necessary to annex a plate in order to follow the calculations by which the writer proves his position.
obj_descr.263: Fragment. A notably large gnomon hole, 13 mm wide and 45 mm deep, is preserved in the top center of the stone.
obj_descr.264:
A blood red color marks the eleven preserved hour lines and three day curves of this dial. There is no red color along the edges near the missing meridian line, and in fragment 7297 the left or meridian edge is finished smooth. The smooth lower edges of fragment 7297 also give some indication of the original shape of the dial. All preserved hour lines continue in red to the top center of the dial where a groove remains in fragment 7296. The two engraved hour lines in fragment 7297 continue beyond the lower day curve without red color. Note that while the hour lines are straight lines, the day curves are broken lines, the top curve most closely resembling a semicircle. The hour lines form the following angles between the left horizon and the eleventh hour: 19, 18, 15.5, 17.2, 14.1, 11, 10, 11, 14.7, 12.8, 17.5. The winter solstice curve consists of the following arcs: 9, 11, 9, 10, 8,,, 8, 11, 8, 10, mm. The equinox curve between the horizon and the third hour line consists of the following arcs: 25, 26, 20 mm. The summer solstice curve between the sixth and eighth hour lines measures: 37, 31 mm.
Die Sonnenuhr stammt aus einer Privatsammlung des späten 19. Jh. und gelangte 1910, mit der (u. E. wahrscheinlichen) Provenienz "Vindonissa" in die Sammlung der Gesellschaft Pro Vindonissa.
obj_descr.265: The publication describes a red copper bayonetlike gnomon. The dial consists of two plane surfaces meeting at an angle of 90 to form the meridian. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are preserved.
obj_descr.266: Two joined fragments; Five hour lines are preserved, not including the meridian. Parts of seven day curves remain. A Latin inscription marks these day curves as shown in the figure.
obj_descr.267: Gibbs: Four dials, north face, south face, west face, east face; British Museum: Parian marble sundial; two oblong plane surfaces; incised radials.
obj_descr.268: Gibbs: Four dials, north face, south face, west face, east face; British Museum: Parian marble sundial; two oblong plane surfaces; incised radials.
obj_descr.269: Gibbs: Four dials, north face, south face, west face, east face; British Museum: Parian marble sundial; two oblong plane surfaces; incised radials.
obj_descr.270: Gibbs: Four dials, north face, south face, west face, east face; British Museum: Parian marble sundial; two oblong plane surfaces; incised radials.
obj_descr.271: Seven hour lines radiate from a central point and cross four concentric circles. The preserved arcs of these circles are emphasized with red color.
obj_descr.272: Gibbs: Lost; Photographs of this dial (negative numbers 54820 and 54821) indicate that it consists of a vertical disk facing east and west. Unfortunately attempts to locate it in the museum´s study collection on the summer of 1971 were unsuccessful. Bonanome: It is disc-shaped with two flat surfaces, only slightly raised with respect to the outer rim. The corbel at the base gives its vertical position, and there is still a trace of the sockets used to secure it to an underlying support – now lost – to assure elevation and visibility. The flat surfaces of this solar instrument have been carved and “rubricated” (i.e., coloured in red) to make their reading easier, since they acted as sequential dials. This means that a dial is designed to be faced to the East, in order to show the morning hours, whereas the other is faced to the West and shows the afternoon hours.; Adam/Severino: Three day curves and six hour lines (including horizon line) are visible.
obj_descr.273: The unbroken lower left edge of this southeast-facing fragment follows the curve of the summer solstice. Parts of all three day curves and one hour line are broken away at the bottom and the right side. All or part of five hour lines remain. A group of five convex flutes decorates the top edge.
obj_descr.274: A gnomon hole is visible in the top of the dial above the meridian. Parts of three day curves and eleven hour lines are visible in a photograph of the dial. Only the meridian continues from the gnomon hole to the bottom edge of the dial. Other hour lines stretch between the solstices.
obj_descr.275: Some lead remains in the gnomon hole in the top surface of this dial. The shadow-receiving surface of this dial is supported by a bull´s head and horns. The rounded back of the dial has the shape of a “feminine idol from the early bronze age.” Eleven hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole across two engraved day curves to the lower edge. The dial´s top surface slopes downward about 15 from horizontal. In making my calculations I have assumed that the summer solstice coincides with the lower edge of the cylindrical surface. Ionescu-Carligel assumes that the two engraved day curves are summer solstice and equinox. He obtains g= 166.7 mm, \phi = 44.7.   Bodenache: Auf einem massiven, breitstirnigen, schön stilisierten Stierkopf eine halbkreisförmige, konkave Sonnenuhr mit radialer und kreisbogenförmiger Unterteilung, die zur Stundenangabe diente. Trotz der oberen Beschädigung ist noch die Stelle zu erkennen, wo der Stab befestigt war, der den Schatten warf.
obj_descr.276: A very fine example of a roofed spherical dial has been found on the island of Tenos (7OO1G) with an inscription identifying it as the work of Andronicus Cyrrestes, the architect who designed the Tower of Winds in Athens in the first century B.C. No other examples of this type of dial are known in Greece or Asia Minor. The dial includes both spherical and planar faces./  Four separate shadow-receiving surfaces face the cardinal points of the compass on this dial. The base below the south-facing surface is flanked by two dolphins. The area below the north-facing surface is inscribed with a lengthy Greek dedication. Three fragments have been restored (probably incorrectly) to the top of the sphere.

obj_descr.280: The designer of the Prosymna globe included a north-facing network of lines which also utilizes the sunlight-shadow boundary as it passes through the hour holes used with the south face. Again intersection between appropriately marked boundary and day curve marked the hour. The resulting network is appropriately similar to the network on a roofed spherical dial, for the shadow boundaries which determine the one are orthogonal to the rays of sunlight which cast an image of the sun on the other. A third network of lines stretches between the east and west hour holes across a shallow hole in the globe´s meridian. I interpret it as a secondary south-facing map of the moving boundary between sunlight and shadow. The three great semicircles which form part of the network are divided by points which would lie along the hourly positions of the boundary at winter solstice (lower semicircle), equinox (middle semicircle), and summer solstice (upper semicircle). Three separate networks of lines have been engraved on this spherical stone. Two great circles on the sphere correspond to the meridian and horizon circles. A conical hole with base 100 mm in diameter pierces the globe at the lower pole.
obj_descr.281: Seven gnomon holes are visible in the top of the dial block. One is on the north-south axis near the north face. Two groups of three are positioned symmetrically above the east and west faces. Four shadow-receiving surfaces have been carved in this block: a south-facing conical surface, a north-facing conical surface, a west-facing quarter sphere, and an east-facing quarter sphere.
obj_descr.282: Seven gnomon holes are visible in the top of the dial block. One is on the north-south axis near the north face. Two groups of three are positioned symmetrically above the east and west faces. Four shadow-receiving surfaces have been carved in this block: a south-facing conical surface, a north-facing conical surface, a west-facing quarter sphere, and an east-facing quarter sphere.

obj_descr.285: The dial faces are cylindrical and hemispherical. Two winged female figures hold the hemisphere in the lower position. A torch and scroll decorate each side of the upper cylinder. A stepped molding outlines the decorated areas and the shadow-receiving surface.
obj_descr.286: The dial faces are cylindrical and hemispherical. Two winged female figures hold the hemisphere in the lower position. A torch and scroll decorate each side of the upper cylinder. A stepped molding outlines the decorated areas and the shadow-receiving surface.
obj_descr.287: Eight hour line and day curve grids are engraved on five differently shaped surfaces. Two winged cherubs flank the cylinder at the top front of the dial. A crescent moon and three stars decorate the lower left corner in front; an eagle decorates the lower right corner. On the right side, the legs of a cherub running toward the back of the dial decorate the top; a piece of drapery in relief blows from back to front in the bottom section. An engraved line following the circumference of the circular section of the surface at the lower left front is the only decoration on the left side. A stepped molding outlines the various shadow-receiving surfaces and decorated areas.

obj_descr.295: Parts of three shadow-receiving surfaces are preserved: left, right, and center. All engraved lines are wide and deep. The rough-finished back is curved to correspond to the front surface.
obj_descr.296: Parts of three shadow-receiving surfaces are preserved: left, right, and center. All engraved lines are wide and deep. The rough-finished back is curved to correspond to the front surface.
obj_descr.297: Parts of three shadow-receiving surfaces are preserved: left, right, and center. All engraved lines are wide and deep. The rough-finished back is curved to correspond to the front surface.
obj_descr.298: Das Gnomonloch ist etwa 5 mm breit und 12 mm tief. Im Inneren sind Bleireste zu erkennen. Ein zweites Loch befindet sich 5 cm unterhalb des Gnomonlochs auf der Meridianlinie und ist kaum 4 mm tief. Die Uhr hat 11 Stundenlinien und eine Horizontlinie. Die Stundenlinien werden von zwei halbkreisfrmigen Bgen geschnitten. Die Bgen haben einen Radius von 45 mm und von 141 mm. Mittelpunkt des kleineren Bogens ist das Gnomonloch des greren Bogens darunter.  Die Stundenlinien verlaufen vom Gnomonloch bis zum Rand der Platte. Die einzelnen Sektoren haben, von der Horizontallinie gegen den Uhrzeigersinn gezhlt, die Winkelgren 17, 16, 14, 15, 13, 13, 16, 14, 15, 15, 16, 16.
obj_descr.299: Inscription on a white block of marble.
obj_descr.300: Found near the temple of Hercules in Pompeii, May 11, 1765.
obj_descr.302: Found on a piece of marble in a wall in Amastris.
obj_descr.303: The inscription is part of a now lost sundial with spherical surface.
obj_descr.304: Found built into a wall of the house of Hussein Tschausch on Kos. The block of stone contained a gnomon hole and an inscription.
obj_descr.305: A small marble base ornamented with a relief margin above and below was found on Lemnos. It contained a Greek inscription.
obj_descr.306: Das Gnomonloch ist mit einer Größe von 32 mm x 20 mm und einer Tiefe von 28 mm relativ groß. Es ist gut erhalten. 11 klar gezeichnete Stundenlinien verlaufen vom unteren Rand der Schattenfläche bis zum Fußpunkt des Gnomons. Der Abstand der Stundenlinien ist gleichmäßig. Die halbkreisförmige Bogenlinie, die die Stundenlinien kreuzt, hat ihren Mittelpunkt im Gnomonfußpunkt. Die Neigung der Vorderfläche ist nicht einheitlich. Sie beträgt über den Füßen 41.5 und im Meridianbereich 38.5. Höhe der Basis: 90 mm.
obj_descr.307: Stark bestoßen; der Gnomon fehlt. Abgebrochen sind die Enden und auf der Ostseite ein großer, auf der Westseite ein kleiner Teil der Basis. Das Äußere der Uhr ohne jeglichen Schmuck. Im Gnomonloch befindeen sich noch Teste der Bleifüllung. Der Gnomonkanal ist falzförmig vertieft. Die gerundete einstufige Basis über einer angedeuteten Bodenplatte lässt die Bearbeitung mit einem Zahneisen erkennen. Deck- und Seitenflächen sind geglättet. Boden und Rückwand sind grob bossiert. Die Rückwand ist außerdem an den Seiten leicht abfallend und nur im mittleren Teil vertikal gearbeitet, was dort zu einem zapfenförmigen Gebilde führt. Im Boden befinden sich zwei Klammerlöcher für eine rückseitige Befestigung. Die Schattenfläche der hohlkegelförmigen Uhr ist präzise gearbeitet.
obj_descr.308: Sonnenuhr, oben gebrochen; auf drei Seiten beschriftet; Staurogramm auf c; ein weiteres Staurogramm (oder Monogramm?) auf b. Das Monument repräsentiert einen Typ Sonnenuhr in mehreren senkrechten Flächen.
obj_descr.309: Frammenti di meridiana in marmo con la raffigurazione die meridiani e die paralleli (lato interno lettere 2,8-3, bordo 3,5). Un´iscrizione è incisa sul lato interno, un´altra sul bordo. L´iscrizione interna alla meridiana riporta l´indicazione dei punti del triangolo entro il quale si allunga l´omba dello gnomone e segna gli estremi della durata dei giorni fra i due solstizi. L´iscrizione incise all´interno poteva contenere anche i segni zodiacali. L´iscrizione sul bordo esterno indica i nomi dei costruttori o dei dedicanti.
obj_descr.310: This is a miniature, discovered in Egypt by W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1884.The dial had been burned and was found in pieces in the remains of a private house from late Ptolemaic times. It lay in seventeen fragments until the spring of 2005, when it was reassembled and studied in detail for the first time. It presents three features that make it unique, or at least unusual, among the extant corps of ancient Greek sundials: it is the only such dial made of ivory; it bears an inscription indicating that the lightning and shading of the undercut front face signaled the equinox; and it was found among its owner´s other effects in a private house. Small portions of the dial (including the remains of the plinth or footing) retain a rich, reddish brown color, but the bulk of the surface is in various shades of grey, as a result of exposure to heat. The dial fragments are extremely fragile. Seven day curves are incised, along with usual lines for the seasonal hours. The floating upper right corner cannot be joined to the main body of the dial, as too much of the ivory has been lost in between. All the incised curves and lines were emphasized with a red material. It shows the spectral signature of hematite.
obj_descr.311: The central shadow-receiving surface of this dial is a convex cylinder with eleven hour lines and three day curves. Ashby publishes a measured drawing by Andreas Coner which gives tw = 3 units, we = 5 1/8 units and es = 17 3/4 units. The central dial is flanked by two deviating vertical dials facing southeast and southwest. Each deviating dial has three day curves divided by five hour lines with a gnomon hole above the meridian. A calendar showing the longest day equal to fifteen hours (\phi=40.56) is engraved on the base below the dial faces.
obj_descr.312: Die sechs erhaltenen Stücke sind wieder zusammengefügt und ergeben eine 2-5 cm dicke Marmorplatte, die auf jeder Seite ein Liniennetz mit ähnlichem Aussehen trägt, nämlich Halbkreisbögen, die durch gerade, zu den hypothetischen Mittelpunkten führende Linien in gleiche Sektoren unterteilt sind. Die Linien sind fein, meist sauber gezogen und haben eine gleich bleibende Breite von etwa 1 mm. Der Stein ist im Bereich der großen Kreisbögen ein wenig gekrümmt. Die eine Fläche trägt eine nur noch teilweise erhaltene Inschrift. Auf ihr verlaufen die Strahlen bis unterhalb des Gnomonkanals, wo sie von einem kleinen Kreisbogen mit einem Radius von ca. 25 mm begrenzt werden. Ihre Verlängerungen treffen sich über der Kante. Auf der gegenüberliegenden Fläche, wo die Linien etwas stärker verwittert sind, gehen sie, zuletzt aber mit unklarer Führung, bis zum Gnomonkanal. Die Radien der beiden großen Kreise betragen auf beiden Seiten 294 mm. Der Gnomonkanal ist durchgängig, das heißt, der ursprüngliche Gnomon ragte beiderseits über die Schattenflächen hinaus. Sein Befestigungsloch wurde vom Gnomonkanal in den dünnen Stein hineingemeißelt. Der Gnomonkanal verläuft schräg zum Stein und damit parallel zur oberen und zur unteren Kante. Der Neigungswinkel der Kanten zur Vertikalen hat einen Wert von etwa 40°, die Ortsbreite für das Amphiareion beträgt 38°19'. Der Stein ist im Bereich der Tagundnachtgleichen etwas dicker und der Gnomon ist auf beiden Seiten so kurz gehalten, dass die Schatten an den Äquinoktien die großen kreisförmigen Datumslinien treffen konnten. Auf der Winterseite, der Inschriftseite, lief der Schatten vom großen Kreisbogen des Herbstäquinoktiums zum kleinen Kreisbogen des Wintersolstitiums, wieder zurück zum Frühjahrsäquinoktium, um dann auf die Sommerseite hinüber zu wechseln, wo er vom Frühjahrsäquinoktium bis zum Herbstäquinoktium blieb.
obj_descr.313: The base of a bronze gnomon in lead fill remains in the top surface above the meridian formed by the intersecting dial surfaces. This well-preserved dial consists of two dial surfaces, each with five engraved hour lines and three day curves, meeting at the meridian; one surface faces southeast, the other southwest. Some hour lines on the right extend beyond the summer solstice, but all seem to be contained within the winter curve.
obj_descr.314: The publication describes a red copper bayonetlike gnomon. The dial consists of two plane surfaces meeting at an angle of 90 to form the meridian. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are preserved.

Unfortunately attempts to locate it in the museum´s study collection on the summer of 1971 were unsuccessful. Bonanome: It is disc-shaped with two flat surfaces, only slightly raised with respect to the outer rim. The corbel at the base gives its vertical position, and there is still a trace of the sockets used to secure it to an underlying support – now lost – to assure elevation and visibility. obj_descr.316: The sketch published in Inscriptiones Graecae was drawn from photographs. [...] Found along a street on the island of Kea.
obj_descr.317: The South side of the sundial is decorated with the prow and rostrum of a ship. On the head of the prora, a small hole is visible, which was probably used as a mounting hole for a decorative figure or ornament of a ship's prow, the acrostolium. Gibbs: A probable gnomon hole can be seen in the top surface of the dial. It is cylindrical, 22 mm in diameter, and 44 mm deep.
obj_descr.318: Gibbs: Two square holes diametrically opposite from each other in the hexagonally shaped top surface of the dial are probably gnomon holes. Gnomons placed in these holes could have served all four shadow-receiving surfaces. The central rectangular hole (132 mm long, 20 mm wide, and 56.5 mm deep) and associated grooves still contain a trace of lead and may have been part of the gnomon system. More probably they held some ornament or additional timekeeping device. The dial is supported by a ship-shaped base decorated on the left and right sides by reliefs depicting bearded giants whose tails end in acanthus leaves. Four separate line grids have been engraved on the transposed halves of the north and south facing conical surfaces. Schaldach: Die beiden Schattenflächen I und II befinden sich auf der Bug-Seite. Die Uhr I zeigt die Nachmittagsstunden, die östliche Uhr II die Vormittagsstunden an. Das Heck unter der N-Seite ist abgebrochen. Die beiden südlichen Schattenflächen sind vorkragend, ihre für die Größe dieser Uhr zu breiten Stundenlinien gehen über die Sommerwendlinien hinaus. Die weggebrochenen äußeren Kanten bildeten jeweils die Mittagslinie. Die Winterwendlinie von I ist nur teilweise erhalten. Auch die beiden Schattenflächen III und IV auf der Nordseite sind symmetrisch angeordnet. Die konkave Höhlung ist hier allerdings nur schwach ausgeprägt und die Linien sind kaum mehr zu erkennen. In der Deckfläche befinden sich an den Stellen A und E die Gnomonlöcher. Sie hielten die Gnomone, welche jeweils zwei Schattenflächen bedienten. Die Löcher B und D sind nur flach und haben vielleicht das Wegrutschen beweglicher Stangen verhindert. Im länglichen Loch C (Weite: 135 mm x 20 mm, Tiefe: 55 mm) befanden sich Reste von einem flexiblen, rötlichen Material (Leder?). Ich vermute mit Basch, dass die Löcher B, C und D eine Art Segel hielten, um das Schiff zu vervollständigen.

Die Uhr I zeigt die Nachmittagsstunden, die östliche Uhr II die Vormittagsstunden an. Das Heck unter der N-Seite ist abgebrochen. Die beiden südlichen Schattenflächen sind vorkragend, ihre für die Größe dieser Uhr zu breiten Stundenlinien gehen über die Sommerwendlinien hinaus. Die weggebrochenen äußeren Kanten bildeten jeweils die Mittagslinie. Die Winterwendlinie von I ist nur teilweise erhalten. Auch die beiden Schattenflächen III und IV auf der Nordseite sind symmetrisch angeordnet. Die konkave Höhlung ist hier allerdings nur schwach ausgeprägt und die Linien sind kaum mehr zu erkennen. In der Deckfläche befinden sich an den Stellen A und E die Gnomonlöcher. Sie hielten die Gnomone, welche jeweils zwei Schattenflächen bedienten. Die Löcher B und D sind nur flach und haben vielleicht das Wegrutschen beweglicher Stangen verhindert. Im länglichen Loch C (Weite: 135 mm x 20 mm, Tiefe: 55 mm) befanden sich Reste von einem flexiblen, rötlichen Material (Leder?). Ich vermute mit Basch, dass die Löcher B, C und D eine Art Segel hielten, um das Schiff zu vervollständigen.
obj_descr.320: The gnomon hole at the left side is 8 mm in diameter. It slants downward at an angle 45 from the horizontal. The right gnomon hole is lead filled. The transposed halves of a dished conical surface form the shadow-receiving area of this dial. The sagitta at the left equinox is about  8 mm; at right, 9 mm. Six hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on each side. The base is a schematic lion´s paw.
obj_descr.321: Kroeper: Two faces of the stone are worked, one has a plane angled surface, the opposite side a conoidal face. Both sides have 12 radial lightly engraved lines on their respective surfaces emanating from the top edge of the stone downward. At the top of the stone is a hole in which originally the shadow throwing, probably, metal rod was placed. Of particular interest in this example are the two faces (PI. V, fig. 1), one for normal use oriented with the face to the south, the other for use near the summer solstice (oriented north).  blogspot.com: The hour marks are set on two opposing sides of this sandstone block. The top side has a cavity for the gnomon.
obj_descr.322: Sonnenuhr, oben gebrochen; auf drei Seiten beschriftet; Staurogramm auf c; ein weiteres Staurogramm (oder Monogramm?) auf b. Das Monument repräsentiert einen Typ Sonnenuhr in mehreren senkrechten Flächen.
obj_descr.323: Sonnenuhr, oben gebrochen; auf drei Seiten beschriftet; Staurogramm auf c; ein weiteres Staurogramm (oder Monogramm?) auf b. Das Monument repräsentiert einen Typ Sonnenuhr in mehreren senkrechten Flächen.
obj_descr.324: Con linee tracciate con vernice rossa. Asticella in bronzo pressoché integra.
obj_descr.326: Non è facile trovare meridiane romane orizzontali complete di tutte le curve di declinazione. Gibbs ne riporta solo un paio. In questo caso c'è una stranezza-mistero: le curve di declinazione non sono sette, bensì solo cinque. Risulta essere l'unico esemplare disegnato con questa particolarità, ma questo lo vedremo tra poco. La lastra di marmo non è completa e della quinta ora è visibile solo un piccolo tratto mentre la prima è invisibile a causa della rottura nella parte sinistra. La linea meridiana si prolunga oltre i due solstizi.
obj_descr.327: Nella catalogazione antica vi è una breve descrizione che dice: Frammento di una meridiana (quarto superiore sinistro) ricoperto di stucco bianco, con gnomone di piombo e raggi incisi e tinti di rosso. larghezza massima 0,37. Una nota di fianco al testo indica: restaurato - vi si è connesso lo gnomone. Ma tale scheda porta un numero di catalogo 1198 e non si tratta di un quarto di sfera superiore sinistra. Probabilmente c'è un diversità della catalogazione delle schede. La descrizione si addice piu' al frammento n° 20495. 17 Due frammenti molto rovinati uniti in malo modo. Possibile identificazione delle linee orarie dalla 2 alla 11. Tracce di vernice rossa su alcune linee orarie. Nella foto a destra si distingue molto bene la forma rettangolare del foro che ospitava lo gnomone e la colata di piombo fuso per bloccarlo.
obj_descr.328: Un bellissimo frammento che conserva le ore dalle 7 alle 11. L'accuratezza del tracciato delle linee testimonia che un tempo era una meridiana davvero ben fatta. Conserva perfettamente la colorazione rossa per ciascuna linea e le due porzioni di solstizi.
obj_descr.329: E' abbastanza grande di dimensioni, essendo di circa mezzo metro di lato. Semplice nel suo schema e completa, mancante pero' di gnomone dove c'è il foro triangolare semipieno di piombo fuso lungo 3,5 cm. Ospitava probabilmente, come nel caso della meridiana orizzontale n° 14131, uno gnomone triangolare "obeliscoide" inclinato come un assostilo. Il tracciato è completo anche dei solstizi e linea equinoziale e la linea meridiana dell'ora Sesta si prolunga in entrambe le direzioni e passando per il centro del buco dello gnomone, fino al termine della lastra di marmo.
obj_descr.330: Piccolo frammento di una meridiana orizzontale abbastanza grande. Si notano solo tre porzioni di linee orarie, probabilmente antimeridiane e questa decorazione che con un foro centrale fa pensare piu' qualcosa di simile ad un calendario.
obj_descr.332: Si tratta di due frammenti (34224 and 34220) della stessa meridiana sferica, erroneamente catalogati con due schede diverse e due numeri di inventario diversi. Per la prima volta il vostro autore ha dimostrato in situ la perfetta corrispondenza dei due frammenti (vedi foto sopra) che uniti ricostruiscono la meridiana sferica quasi per intero. Sono visibili quasi tutte e undici le linee orarie e le tre curve di declinazione. Il reperto è molto rovinato. Nella foto sotto, i due frammenti separati.
obj_descr.333: Scheda originale: Meridiana in marmo. Alt. 4,5 cm; lung. 13 cm.
obj_descr.334: Meridiana conica. E' presente la base dello stilo in bronzo originale.
obj_descr.336: Severino(2003): Meridiana Sferica in tufo senze inventario. Provenienza ignote. Il Dr. Peppino Cesarano, funzionario della Soprintendenza di Pompei, e' andato ad indagare per nostro conto ad Ercolano sull'esistenza di queste meridiane. Ha trovato, infatti, la meridiana di cui sopra che, per quanto concerne la descrizione della conca sferica e delle linee orarie si trova in accordo con la scheda n° 1031G di Gibbs che pero' la colloca nella "Casa dell'Atrio a Mosaico", mentre questa ha provenienza sconosciuta e le misure non concordano con quelle di Gibbs. Una discrepanza difficilmente risolvibile. In accordo con la scheda Gibbs, la meridiana presenta tracce di nove linee orarie con il particolare non molto comune che tutte si prolungano oltre la curva del solstizio invernale fino alla base dove era collocato lo gnomone. Purtroppo la Gibbs nulla dice per quanto riguarda la forma del reperto oltre al fatto che rileva essere in marmo bianco, mentre questa è in tufo. Altezza 25 cm; larghezza 33 cm; Foto di P. Cesarano ERCOLANO
obj_descr.338: Tre fori nello spessore superiore, posteriore liscia.
obj_descr.339: Gibbs: The engraved lines on this dial face include five hour lines, the winter solstice, the equinox, and the summer solstice. The dial appears to have been made to face southeast.  Severino: Scheda del museo : N° 2 lastre di marmo bianco, centinate ad un quarto di cerchio da un lato con la parte in piano incisa con 5 segni messi nel senso dell’angolo a raggiungere l’altro segno fatto in modo da seguire la curva spezzata nella parte centrale e partente da un lato a raggiungere l’altro, tali incisioni sono 3, nello spessore delle lastre e cioè nell parte centinata ove vanno a convergere le linee vi sono dei segni fatti per misura m. 0,72 x 0.55 x 0.028. Spezzata in 13 frammenti. Provenienza Nemi (Valle Giardino). Entrata al museo in marzo-febbraio 1925. Ammissione Aprile 1931. Prezzo £. 50. Vecchia collocazione, Olearie, settore 19 A 2° ripiano. La descrizione è fatta ovviamente da una persona completamente estranea alla gnomonica ed all’astronomia in genere. E’ importante notare che la scheda cataloga in un unico numero di inventario, il 112134, due lastre di marmo che si crede appartenenti ad un unico reperto. In realtà le due lastre di marmo rappresentano due meridiane verticali declinanti complementari, ben distinte. Una occidua, l’altra ortiva. Alla seconda lastra che rappresenta la meridian occidua e che doveva essere posizionata a 90 gradi circa (ad angolo retto) con la presente, le daremo convenzionalmente e provvisoriamente il numero di inventario 112134 bis, per distinguerla dal primo reperto. Continuando con le annotazione, rileviamo che questa meridiana è stata pubblicata anche da Gibbs al numero del suo catalogo 5016 per la quale ripete quanto diceva già l’Antonini al numero 10 che era stata vista in Casa De Angelis a Tivoli. Fatto sta che al Museo ci è arrivata proveniente da Nemi.
obj_descr.341: Descrizione della scheda del Museo: Frammento di lastra marmorea con meridiana. Marmo bianco a grana media. La lastra è fratturata a sinistra e superiormente, gli altri bordi sono conservati. Della meridiana disegnata con sottili linee incise si conserva la parte centrale a destra…. La parte oraria conservata è quella di sinistra, cioè la parte delle ore antimeridiane, come si vede dalla foto. La meridiana è davvero piccolina e molto fragile, ma pregevole nelle incisioni e nella fattura. Ben conservato il foro dove era alloggiato lo gnomone. Sono visibili 7 linee orarie, la linea equinoziale e le curve dei solstizi. Il reperto è spezzato in 6 frammenti ed incollato. Viene conservato in una busta di plastica trasparente sigillata..
obj_descr.342: Sei linee orarie visibili. Equinozi e solstizi. L´incavo per lo gnomone e parte del basamento.
obj_descr.343: Linee orarie visibili 3. Parte della curva del solstizio invernale.
obj_descr.344: Manca buona parte del quarto di sfera sinistra. Presenti 7 linee orarie dalla Prima alla Settima e le tre curve di declinazione. Manca una scheda e qualsiasi descrizione. Ignota la provenienza. Ritrovamento casuale nei depositi da parte della consegnataria Panatta.
obj_descr.345: Rifatto in gesso nella parte anteriore.
obj_descr.347: Orologio solare di travertino ricavato in un parallelepipedo, manca lo gnomone; la parte inferiore poggia su mensole.
obj_descr.348: Orologio solare su lastra rettangolare di pietra ad angoli smussati, mancante dello gnomone che doveva essere in bronzo: sulla faccia posteriore è incisa una ruota con vari elementi ornamentali, mentre una decorazione ad onde marine corre sui fianchi.
obj_descr.349: Il blocco rientra dopo un tratto di cm. 8 formando una faccia rettangolare con scheggiature; su cui si trova l’iscrizione, su due linee (alt. delle lettere cm. 2,5) non completamente leggibili. La parte superiore aggetta e si incurva a formare la concavità su cui sono incise le linee delle ore (dovevano essere nove) tagliate dalle linee orizzontali dei solstizi e degli equinozi, alla base della quale si notano 2 rosette a 5 petali rigonfi, attorno ad un punto centrale. La faccia superiore è frammentaria. La faccia superiore è frammentaria, ma da due schegge ricomposte si ritrova il piano originale, con due fori al centro in cui era infisso lo gnomone. Le altre facce sono lisce e squadrate.
obj_descr.350: Esto conlleva que cerca del Solsticio de verano tengamos un día con horas de casi 75 minutos, y en los alrededores del solsticio de invierno las horas sean de unos 48 minutos. El reloj funciona bien sólo los días de los equinoccios en que tanto el día como la noche duran 12 horas. Tiene varias características que lo hacen algo distinto a la mayoría de los que se han encontrado: - La casi totalidad de los instrumentos de este tipo conservados tienen la superficie excavada para las horas formadas por una concavidad cónica y nuestro caso es de los pocos en que la excavación es cilíndrica, como parece ser que lo es también el encontrado en el arroyo Mazarracín en Toledo y conservado en el Museo de la Santa Cruz de esa capital. - Carece de líneas de declinación de solsticios y equinoccios. - El corte superior que debería ser horizontal, no lo es, teniendo una inclinación cercana a los 4 grados. Está fabricado en un bloque de arenisca cementada y, a expensas de un estudio posterior mas profundo, yo lo catalogaría como un "Hemicyclium" o Hemicírculo cilíndrico.
obj_descr.351: Severino: Ad Apricena, in provincia di Foggia, è stata rinvenuta da diversi anni, nella Masseria Amorusi nella Murgetta di Apricena, una splendida meridiana del tipo conico non compresa in Gibbs. Essa è attualmente conservata nei locali del Municipio ed è oggetto di studio della locale associazione archeologica guidata da Gaetano Lo Zito che ringrazio per la gentile collaborazione e concessione delle foto digitali da egli stesso eseguite per questo lavoro. Risulta che la meridiana è stata oggetto di studio da parte di alcuni studiosi tedeschi di cui pero' non è dato sapere altro, probabilmente per l'elevato interesse storico ed epigrafico dell'iscrizione presente sulla base del monumento e non ancora decifrata. Sono presenti 11 linee orarie e nessuna curva solstiziale ed equinoziale. E' rotta sugli spigoli esterni e non presenta tracce di foro gnomonico (il che è alquanto strano). Sotto l'iscrizione, sembra di scorgere due lettere DD che starebbero ad indicare forse l'anno di costruzione, il 200 d.C.  Scheidt: Eine ebenso nahezu vollständige sphärische Uhr aus Apricena (RUSSI 1976, Abb.4) verfügt zwar auf ihrer Basis über eine nicht häufig anzutreffende (römische) Inschrift, welche die Uhr als Stiftung bzw. Schenkung eines 'Euelpistus Aug(usti)' ausweist, jedoch über keinerlei Datumskurven. Trotzdem ist eine Bewertung ihrer astronomischen Qualität nicht unmöglich.
obj_descr.352: This sundial dates from the Imperial Era and is an exceptional example of a scaphe, or bowl sundial, with a hole to let through a ray of sunlight. The interior is engraved with lines and inscriptions in Greek; the spot lit by the sunbeam would give the month, day, and hour. This sundial is in the shape of a skyphos or drinking vessel, a fashionable shape for luxury Roman tableware at the end of the republic. The exterior is decorated with oak twigs and acorns. The vessel has a handle on each side. The exterior of the marble bowl is decorated with concentric moldings, and, as with similar vessels made of metal, the sides are decorated with a carved foliage motif, in this case oak twigs with acorns. On one side of the vessel are a round hole and a thick tenon, which would originally have been part of a mortise and tenon joint attaching the sundial to its pedestal. The sundial was positioned vertically with the hole uppermost and the concave bowl facing the observer. The interior of the bowl is engraved with a network of curving lines accompanied by Greek inscriptions, some abbreviated, giving the dates of the Roman calendar. The broadest division corresponds to the summer solstice, 24 June, and the narrowest the winter solstice, 25 December. The fan of eleven lines dividing the curving sections marks the length of the twelve daytime hours of the Roman day, which were longer in summer and shorter in winter. The hole in the vessel let through a ray of sunlight that marked the month, day, and hour, moving round the bowl as the position of the sun changed. The opening would originally have been partly closed off with a bronze plaque, restricting the opening and thus focusing the beam more precisely, but this has been lost. The sundial was made for use at a latitude of 41. If it was found in Carthage, which is at a lower latitude, it must have been transported there after manufacture.
obj_descr.353: La meridiana è esposta nel chiostro dell'ex convento di S. Francesco e pare non sia mai stata studiata fino ad ora. Dalle foto effettuate da Luca, la meridiana si presenta come una meridiana sferica in discreto stato conservativo, quasi integra, in pietra porosa. Una parte del basamento è rotta, ma la conca sferica conserva intatte le undici line orarie temporarie piu' le curve dei solstizi ed equinozi. Si può notare che in corrispondenza delle linee orarie Terza, sesta e Nona, esistono dei piccoli trattini profondi e trasversali. Probabilmente la meridiana fu utilizzata nel medioevo dai monaci per il computo anche delle ore Canoniche. Si nota bene anche la forma dell'incavo in cui era alloggiato lo gnomone. Fino ad un decennio fa la meridiana era conservata presso i magazzini della Soprintendenza di Firenze, poi trasferita nel chiostro suddetto. Una targa riporta che risalirebbe all'età repubblicana, prima età imperiale. Sconosciuta la provenienza e i dettagli del ritrovamento.
obj_descr.354: Il Museo Civico Archeologico e d’Arte Sacra del Palazzo Corboli in Asciano, Siena, custodisce una preziosa testimonianza, rimasta piuttosto nell’ombra fino ad oggi, dell’arte dei Romani di misurare il tempo con gli orologi solari. Non censita da Gibbs, non pubblicata da altri autori moderni, questa meridiana romana è un interessante esemplare in travertino di cui però non si hanno altre notizie, anche riguardo al suo ritrovamento e alla sua provenienza. Non c’era modo di vedere come era fatto questo strumento se non andare personalmente al Museo di Palazzo Corboli, ma la dott.sa Milena Pagni, è stata così gentile da mettermi a disposizione alcune preziose immagini del reperto che mi hanno consentito di vedere di cosa si tratta. Dall’immagine sopra, la meridiana si mostra in una bella prospettiva. Lo stato di conservazione non è molto buono, ma i suoi lineamenti e la sua forma sono ben distinguibili. La parte centrale del tracciato orario, ben visibile, mostra che esso fu realizzato con una buona precisione, certamente da mano esperta e che la concavità su cui giacciono fu concepita essere una sezione conica. E’ quindi una meridiana del tipo “Hemicyclium ad enclima succisum”2 classificabile come conica. La foto permette ancora di dedurre: - che le linee orarie originarie erano 11 e che se ne conservano in buono stato quelle dall’ora Terza all’ora Decima. - Sul bordo inferiore si vede tracciato molto bene un circolo che delimita la lunghezza delle linee orarie e che coincide, quasi sempre, con la curva solstiziale estiva; - Non sembra rilevarsi la presenza di un circolo equinoziale (linea equinoziale); - Risulta abbastanza chiara, anche se tenue in foto, la presenza della curva solstiziale invernale, come un piccolo semicircolo; - Tutte le linee orarie proseguono oltre il detto circolo del solstizio invernale per convergere approssimativamente nel punto di impianto dello gnomone3. - Nella parte superiore dell’orologio si vedono chiaramente i resti della base di piombo in cui era impiantato lo gnomone in piano orizzontale; - Il disegno della base dell’orologio sembra essere quello di solito comune a molti orologi solari greco-romani, cioè il rilievo di un tronco semicilindrico.
obj_descr.355: Der hellbraun/cremefarbene Kalk(sand)stein weist eine mittenzentriert ausgearbeitete, leicht abgeplattete (Azentrizität in Y 0,926) Halbkugel mit einem mittleren Radius von 98.5 mm auf. Elf Stundenlinien schneiden die sieben eingravierten Datumslinien. Am Boden der Halbkugel, dem ursprünglichen (?) Sitz des (fehlenden) Gnomons, ist ein Loch von ca. 70 mm Durchmesser herausgebrochen; ferner geht von Ost nach West ein (nach Auffindung nachträglich geklebter) Riss durch die Uhr. Der Stein zeigt in römischen Maßeinheiten interessante Abmessungen. Seine Höhe von DIGITI VII, die Breite von genau PES I und die Tiefe von CUBITUS I lässt vermuten, dass er eventuell als Baustein /Konstruktionselement (?) vorgesehen war. Der Durchmesser eines konzentrischen, horizontalen Kreisanrisses mit PES I und der horizontale Radius der Kugelausnehmung mit UNCIAE IIII zeigt ebenso erstaunlich glatte römische Abmessungen. Der Gnomon (Eisen/Bronze?) ist später herausgebrochen worden. Vielleicht war auch unten in der Halbkugel neben dem Gnomonsitz ein Loch zum Abfluss des Regenwassers vorgesehen.
obj_descr.357: The sundial was cut out of a marble slab. The silhouette, resembling the body of a female is shown on Fig. 4. The sundial is mounted and fixed onto a high place. Not much effort was employed on processing the marble. Greater emphasis was laid, however, on inscribing the lines and curves onto the shadow receiving surface. The eleven hour-lines originate from the base of the presently missing gnomon and extend towards the frontal edge. The midday line (for the 6tb hour) had previously been marked on the frontal plane - a mark also common for a number of other specimens.
obj_descr.360: Descrizione : (da Macchia) “Databile fra la fine del II e l’inizio del I secolo a.C., è costituita di un blocco di parallelepipedo in calcare poroso, grigio chiaro, scurito esternamente dalla patina. E’ priva dello gnomone. Nella conca sono incise 11 linee orarie temporarie attraversate da un segmento circolare tracciato a 4 cm dal foro dello gnomone, e da una sola linea diurna di declinazione (equinozi) circa verso la metà della conca. Il blocco era incassato, probabilmente, per 2 cm come fa pensare l’incisione lunga 3 cm sotto l’iscrizione ed al centro. Alla stessa altezza, in ciascuno dei due lati del blocco, si nota un piccolo foro quadrangolare che, all’interno del blocco stesso, piega ad angolo retto, riuscendo sul fondo : qui, probabilmente, erano inseriti i perni che lo tenevano fermo al suo sostegno. Sulla superficie lavorata sono presenti scheggiature e graffi più o meno profondi causati da lavori agricoli. La rottura di uno spigolo della base ha portato la perdita di una lettera. Interessante è l’iscrizione umbra che occupa la parte inferiore del blocco. Le lettere evidenziate da una incisione profonda e regolare sono alte 3 cm ; quelle del secondo rifo sono leggermente più grandi e distanziate. Il testo dell’epigrafe, letto alla maniera etrusca da destra a sinistra, è il seguente : [ ?p.] nurtinus. Ia. T. uferie[r cvestur. Farariur, che può essere tradotto così : [.]P (ubilii ?) (filius) Nortinus, la(ntus) T(iti) (filius) Aufidius quaestores far(r )arii. Nortinus ed Aufidius sono gentili già documentati a Mevania, ma la citazione dei “quaestores fararii”, cioè alimentari, o frumentari, rappresenta una novità. Nella fase municipale di Bevagna, I quaestores aerari erano già menzionati. Per questo motivo, la meridiana è da datarsi in epoca precedente, verosimilmente attorno alla metà del II secolo a.C.”
obj_descr.361: The specimen from the Shumen Fortress have ten hour lines, which verifies the hypothesis for the existence of fortress sundials in antiquity, used for regulation of the change of dayguard.
obj_descr.362: The specimen from the Shumen Fortress have ten hour lines, which verifies the hypothesis for the existence of fortress sundials in antiquity, used for regulation of the change of dayguard.
obj_descr.363: The specimens found at the fortress are heavily fragmented and were primitivly made. The day length was divided into 5 parts.
obj_descr.364: Base con una lastra con entrambe le superfici verticali incise con tracciati orari ed iscrizioni greche (probabile orologio est-ovest, meridiano-occiduo come l' esemplare conservato nel museo dell' Abbazia greca di S. Nilo a Grottaferrata). Esemplare di rilevante importanza quindi.
obj_descr.366: Severino: Il frammento è grande circa 30 cm e sembrerebbe appartenere ad un orologio solare emisferico. Si vedono porzioni di 6 linee orarie e due curve di declinazione corrispondenti al solstizio invernale e all'equinozio. Stranamente però non si nota un foro o incavo per l'alloggiamento dello gnomone sul bordo superiore in corrispondenza dell'ora Sesta. Ciò potrebbe essere spiegato ipotizzando uno gnomone disposto in modo diverso, come per esempio perpendicolarmente nel centro della vasca emisferica. In tal caso, solo il vertice dell'asta fornirebbe l'indicazione oraria e calendariale. Wagner: Der erhaltene Teil ist ausreichend, sie nahezu vollständig rekonstruieren zu können. Die Datums- und Stundenlinien, die auf der Innenseite der Sonnenuhr noch zu erkennen sind, wurden mit großer Präzision genau für die Ortsbreite des Martberg gemeißelt.  Nach eingehender Untersuchung des Altfundes aus dem 19. Jahrhundert durch Herrn Schaldach können wir uns nun sicher sein, dass der Tychicos-Stein und das Bruchstück der Sonnenuhr einst zusammengehörten. Dafür gibt es mehrere Hinweise: Beide Objekte sind aus dem selben Sandstein gefertigt. Der Innenradius der Sonnenuhr und der Plattform des Tychicos Steines stimmen genau über ein. Außerdem befindet sich in der Mitte des original Fundstückes der Rest eines eisernen Stiftes, der einstmals das Gnomon, der Zeiger der Sonnenuhr war.
obj_descr.367: Small fragment of a marble conical sundial, broken at the bottom, on the right and on the left side, preserving the hole for the support of a metal pointer on the top.
obj_descr.369: White marble columnar altar; the diameter of the top surface, which is slightly ovel, is 0.78 (north-south), 0.885 (west to east), to serve as a sundial. Inscribed on the top surface; there is a hole where the gnomon may have stood.
obj_descr.370: Ab der Stundenlinie für den Anfang der 9. Stunde (s9) bis hoch zur 11. Stunde der Nachtgleiche (Äquinoktium) (e11) ist die (Ost-) Kante der Uhr zerstört. Diese vordere Bruchfläche zeigt keine Flächenbearbeitungsspuren, sodass man von einer ursprünglichen Existenz der gesamten Anzeigefläche bis zur 12. Stunde der SSW (s12 = Horizont der Uhr) ausgehen kann. Eine Nachgravur der Nachtgleiche-Kurve und eine Verlängerung der Stundenlinie 11 (e11) in den oberen Bereich der vorderen Bruchfläche ist offensichtlich, eine weitere Gravur auf der Anzeigefläche findet sich im oberen Teil der Stundenlinie 7. Erhalten ist ein Teil der bearbeiteten Horizontalfläche; mit dieser Fläche als Referenzhorizont der Uhr erhöht sich die Signifikanz der astronomisch-mathematischen Analyse des Fundstücks. Der Sitz des Gnomons (besser zu erkennen in den Abb.7 und 8) zeigt Spuren einer Bearbeitung mit einem hohlkehlartigen Werkzeug. Bleispuren (der Gnomon aus z.B. Bronze wurde meist - wie auch in anderen Technikbereichen die Bronzeklammern zur Fixierung div. Steinverbindungen - mit Blei 'eingeklebt') wurden nicht entdeckt. Da die Seitenflächen und auch der erhaltene Teil der vorderen Front lediglich flächenbearbeitet sind - Dekorationen sind an keiner Stelle erkennbar - kann man auch auf die mögliche Ausführung der fehlenden Basis schließen.
obj_descr.371: Un’altra straordinaria scoperta viene da una foto di Thomas Olsson che ha visitato, in due settimane dell’estate 2008, Istanbul, Selçuk e Pamukkale in Turchia. Nel sito archeologico di età romana di Pamukkale (l’antica Hierapolis, vedi in fondo all’articolo) Olsson ha avuto modo di vedere e, per nostra fortuna, fotografare uno monumento davvero singolare: un orologio solare monumentale unico al mondo nel suo stile. La Turchia si rivela ancora una sorprendente fonte di reperti gnomonici lasciati in eredità dagli antichi romani. Una seconda fortuna è che Olsson ha realizzato una foto ad alta definizione permettendoci di vedere l’orologio quasi come se fossimo sul posto, davanti ad esso. Grazie a questa foto possiamo apprezzare due caratteristiche uniche della tipologia di orologi solari “hemicylium” sferici: la suddivisione oraria e lo gnomone. Ciò che colpisce sono le dimensioni e subito il fatto di vedere incise nella superficie sferica una quantità di linee mai viste su un orologio solare di questo tipo. Inoltre le linee orarie non sono realizzate come nella semplice tipologia degli orologi ad hemicyclium, cioè incise nella superficie sferica con solchi di circa 2-3 mm di larghezza e profondità. Qui siamo di fronte ad uno stile che si riscontra raramente negli orologi solari.
obj_descr.373: Come si vede dalle immagini, si tratta di un orologio multiplo formato, per quanto si può evincere, almeno da un orologio “hemicyclium” sferico superiore e di un orologio verticale meridionale nella parte inferiore. Sono ben visibili cinque linee orarie nella superficie sferica superiore e sei linee orarie nella parte destra dell’orologio verticale in basso. Nell’ingrandimento dell’immagine è possibile vedere che i tracciati orari sono stati realizzati con molta cura ed abilità e stanno a dimostrare l’alto grado di tecnica raggiunto dagli artigiani gnomonisti nel II secolo a.C. Si conserva ancora il foro per lo gnomone orizzontale dell’orologio verticale dove, subito sotto, si vede la linea orizzontale di “alba-tramonto”. Le dimensioni del reperto date dalla scheda archeologica sono di 20 cm di altezza, 23 cm di larghezza e 14 cm di spessore. Nella figura sopra ho tentato un’approssimativa ricostruzione della forma e delle dimensioni. Rispettando le proporzioni del reperto, esso doveva essere largo approssimativamente 46 cm ed alto circa 60 cm per inglobare l’orologio verticale.
obj_descr.374: Come si vede dalle immagini, si tratta di un orologio multiplo formato, per quanto si può evincere, almeno da un orologio “hemicyclium” sferico superiore e di un orologio verticale meridionale nella parte inferiore. Sono ben visibili cinque linee orarie nella superficie sferica superiore e sei linee orarie nella parte destra dell’orologio verticale in basso. Nell’ingrandimento dell’immagine è possibile vedere che i tracciati orari sono stati realizzati con molta cura ed abilità e stanno a dimostrare l’alto grado di tecnica raggiunto dagli artigiani gnomonisti nel II secolo a.C. Si conserva ancora il foro per lo gnomone orizzontale dell’orologio verticale dove, subito sotto, si vede la linea orizzontale di “alba-tramonto”. Le dimensioni del reperto date dalla scheda archeologica sono di 20 cm di altezza, 23 cm di larghezza e 14 cm di spessore. Nella figura sopra ho tentato un’approssimativa ricostruzione della forma e delle dimensioni.
